data.title: [Sign] Pulse of the River Wayside #128a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Pulse of the River Wayside. 3 minutes Half-buried logs laid horizontally define the edge between this narrow parking area along the river and a narrow grass surface picnic area with a table. At the far end of the grassy section is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with a brightly colored illustration that assembles, in one scene, many of the plants and animals living in this river habitat. Green ferns, pillows of yellow-green mosses, and plants with purple berries grow low to the ground. Bright red shrubs growing beneath green pine trees and deciduous trees with yellow, red, and green leaves line the riverbanks. Slim gray river otters and brown beavers with rounded flat tails are on the bank and in the water. A brown frog hides among fallen leaves while a gray bird pulls a worm from the ground. A blue, white and red Kingfisher perches on a branch, a brown and white Osprey watches for fish from a dead tree branch, a red-headed duck with a gray body stands on a river rock, and a bald eagle with a white head and white tailfeathers, flies above the river, its long black wings extended. In the river, red and yellow trout keep to a deep pool, and schools of salmon with bright red markings swim upstream. On the top left of the panel text reads: Pulse of the River. The Sol Duc River launches its conversation with the landscape at 5,000 feet near High Divide. A trickle of mountain water feeds tiny rivulets that merge into streams. The route steepens, waters plunge down hanging paths carved by Ice Age glaciers. Fallen old-growth leaves, logs and branches change the course of the river, crafting pools that provide crucial habitat for beaver, mink, river otter, salmon and salamanders. Tumbling rocks and abrasive sediments create fresh rhythms as the river flows to sea. The Sol Duc River begins and ends with gentleness, but its overriding temperament is vigorous. It is rarely hushed, never resting in one pool for long. Time is its vehicle, change a constant companion. Text in the lower right reads: Coho Cadence. A unique stock of coho salmon with unusual behavior inhabits the Sol Duc River. While most stocks of coho swim up western Washington rivers in October and November, when water levels are high, summer coho enter the Sol Duc in July when stream flows are low. They spawn from late September to November. Winter steelhead and cutthroat trout also swim in these silvery waters.

data.title: [Sign] Washington Geology Wayside #164a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Washington Geology Wayside. 3 minutes The header on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel reads, Washington Geology. Below, text reads: Tsunamis. Devastating waves called tsunamis can strike Washington’s coast at any time. These giant waves are usually caused by great undersea earthquakes. Such earthquakes can occur along the Cascadia Subduction Zone, one of the largest active faults in North America. This fault zone lies 32 to 70 miles offshore and roughly parallels the coast. A tsunami on the Washing Coast may also result from an earthquake striking areas as far away as Alaska or Japan. Tsunamis are dangerous and destructive. They have struck the Washington coast repeatedly and will again in the future. Tsunamis can follow within minutes of an earthquake. They move rapidly, but quickly run out of water as they sweep inland and uphill. Flooding can occur several miles inland along rivers and streams. Remember, most tsunamis are not solitary giant waves; instead, many large waves. What to do to escape a tsunami. Drop, cover, and hold during an earthquake. After the earthquake, immediately move uphill or inland. Do not return to the beach after the first tsunami wave – more waves may arrive for several hours. Wait for official notice from authorities that the danger has passed before returning to the beach. For additional information, contact the Washington Emergency Management Division 1-800-562-6108 or your local Emergency Management Division: Clallam County 1-360-417-2305. In the center of the panel, a rectangular diagram illustrates this text: Cross Section. A portion of the Earth’s crust, called The Juan de Fuca Plate, is moving away from the Pacific Plate, several hundred miles off Washington’s coast. The Juan de Fuca Plate is being forced under the North American Plate. The geologic process is called subduction. On the left side of the panel is a map of the west coasts of Washington and Oregon. In the Pacific Ocean, a dark red line marks the location of the Cascadia Subduction Zone. A caption reads: The earth’s surface consists of a series of plates. These plates are constantly shifting and sliding over, under, or past each other. When a sudden movement occurs between two plates, we experience an earthquake.

data.title: [Sign] Wild Coast Wayside #164b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Wild Coast Wayside. 1 minute Be advised. Driftwood may be scattered on the beach blocking clear access to the wayside. On this 4-foot-tall upright wayside panel, text in the bottom right corner reads: Wild Coast. The sea makes the rules. Hiking this long stretch of wilderness beach, you may have to climb headlands, cross numerous streams, enter a cocoon of fog, or follow animal tracks in the sand. There are no sheltered lagoons. If you ignore the tides, storm waves may trap you against a sheer cliff. Find solitude, or a whale’s jawbone, or a kind of bird you’ve never seen before. Filling the top half of the panel is a blue and white drawing of a wave hitting the rocky shoreline below high tree topped hills. A sea stack is offshore. In the bottom left corner, a blue and white drawing shows a hiker holding a hiking pole while traversing a jumble of rocks at the base of a hill, the ocean in the background.

data.title: Mora Ranger Station
data.listingDescription: Open intermittently in summer as staffing levels permit, with information and bear canisters. Self-register wilderness camping permits available year-round. For more information on Wilderness Information Center locations and hours go to https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm. Nearest accessible restrooms at Rialto Beach or the nearby Mora campground.

images.altText: A one-story beige building with a sign that says "Mora Ranger Station."
images.caption: The Mora Ranger Station. Photo by D. Archeluta/NPS.

data.bodyText: Open intermittently in summer as staffing levels permit, with information and bear canisters. Self-register wilderness camping permits available year-round. Click here for more information on Wilderness Information Center locations. Nearest accessible restrooms at Rialto Beach or the nearby Mora campground.
data.audioDescription: Mora Ranger Station. 1 minutes A wooden brown sign at the entrance to the ranger station parking lot has white text that reads: Mora Ranger Station. Olympic National Park. Elevation 32 feet. The National Park Service arrowhead logo is attached to the left side of the sign. Beyond the sign on the right are parking spaces. A sidewalk in front of the parking spaces leads to the far-left end of the lot where the ranger station is located. Midway along the sidewalk is a roof covered bulletin board with changing park information. The ranger station is a light green one-story building with a metal roof and windows on each side. The entrance is in the front right corner of the building. A water fountain is located near the entrance. Park information is posted on the outside wall of the building on the right near the entrance.

data.title: Mora Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop C

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

data.bodyText: Campground registration and restrooms for Loop C, Mora Campground
data.audioDescription: Mora Campground Registration Loop C. 2 minutes Along the loop road is a white, rectangular restroom building with a blue metal roof. The surface around the building is concrete. The women’s room is on the left short side of the building, and the men’s room is on right short side of the building. Be advised. Short wooden posts stick out of the ground in grassy areas in front of the restroom. Outside the men’s room door is a roof covered bulletin board kiosk. In the center is a self-pay camping registration board, a vertical box with 20 square sections in four horizontal rows. Each square is numbered and corresponds to an individual campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with slots for dropping registration payment receipts into individual squares. To the left of the registration board is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. A 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing payment envelopes stands in front of and to the left of the kiosk. It has a slot at the top for slipping in the envelope. Notices posted on the bulletin board include campground registration instructions, campground regulations, a site map of the campground, pet regulations, rules about campfire wood, nearest services, a notice to contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency, and a map of the Mora area. Across from the kiosk is a 3-foot-tall stone water station. It’s two spigots face the kiosk. A sign on top reads, no dishwashing. To the left of the kiosk an asphalt path leads into the forest of tall pine trees. A recycle bin and garbage dumpster are located along the roadway to the left of the restroom building.

data.title: Mora Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop D

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

data.bodyText: Campground registration and restrooms for Mora Campground, Loop D
data.audioDescription: Mora Campground Registration Loop D. 1 minute Here, in the campground is a roof-covered bulletin board with information about the campground and park. Attached in the center is the campground registration board, a framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. To the left of the board is a brown and blue box holding campground registration envelopes. Standing to the left is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope. To the right of the bulletin board is a restroom building with entrance doors on each side. The women’s room is on the left and the men’s room is on the right.

data.title: Salmon Cascades Overlook

images.altText: A fish leaping up cascading water.
images.caption: Salmon Cascades. Photo by G. Longenbaugh.

data.bodyText: Viewing platform at Salmon Cascades
data.audioDescription: Salmon Cascade Overlook. 3 minutes Be advised, tree roots and rocks protrude onto the trail surface in places. At the end of the trail is a wooden platform overlooking the cascades. The left side railing and one-half of the front railing on the left are about four feet high. The remainder of the front railing and the right side are lower, about three feet high. Upstream is to the left, where flat, dark green water flowing from left to right, soon meets rocks of many sizes becoming frothy white as it cascades over dark brown boulders and rocks of various sizes. Changes in creek bed elevation from high to low create a series of water falls until finally downstream, the water flattens out again. The light brown rocks lining the river are rough in texture and covered in places with green moss. On the far riverbank, small deciduous trees with white bark stand in front of a dense forest of green pine trees. Just before the platform on the left side of the trail, is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel titled, Leaps of a Lifetime. Filling the panel’s background is a color cutaway illustration of a creek, two-thirds underwater and one third above. Underwater in the foreground, three salmon swim in shallow water above a gravelly creek bottom. One has bright red sides with a green and black spotted back, a hook nose that overhangs its mouth, a fin on its back and three fins on its belly. The other two salmon are greener with black spots and have pointed noses. In the near background, red and green salmon swim above a deep pool, and in the far background, two salmon leap out of the water at the base of a waterfall on their journey upstream. Text at the top left reads: Strength, endurance, instinct - how do tools of survival guide you through life’s challenges? Watch these powerful forces at work as coho salmon leap 11 feet up Salmon Cascades. Born in gravelly river beds above the cascades, thousands of juvenile coho salmon memorize river scents on their 70 mile swim to sea. For up to two years coho range hundreds of miles from Oregon to British Columbia. Ocean temperatures and salinity, angle of the sun and magnetic fields help guide them back to the Sol Duc River. These unique summer Coho enter the river in July when water levels are low and they can navigate the cascades. By recalling river scents, about 1,000 coho return to their birthplace from late summer to early fall. When they spawn and die, coho salmon bring new life. Their marine nutrients benefit forests and over 130 wildlife species. A caption in the bottom right corner reads: Do coho salmon share all their secrets of survival? Sometimes, when nature envelops us with wonder, and we are left with more curiosities than conclusions.

data.title: Seven Lakes Basin Trail Junction

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

data.bodyText: Connection to backcountry routes. Consult the Wilderness Information Center for backcountry trips.
data.audioDescription: Seven Lakes Basin Trail Junction. 1 minute Be advised. The trail is uneven in spots with many tripping hazards due to protruding rocks and tree roots. In places, logs have been laid across the trail to create steps. At this trail junction, a wooden sign indicates the Seven Lakes Basin Loop Trail continues straight ahead. Deer Lake and Lover’s Lane are also reached by heading in this up trail direction. Sol Duc Falls Campground is down trail. Here, the trail branches off to the right where it crosses a bridge above Sol Duc Falls ending at the Falls overlook. Continuing straight ahead, the trail passes through a forest of tall pine trees and dense understory of young trees, shrubs, ferns and mosses. The river is on the right. Further along, the trail splits again. Lovers Lane Trail continues to the right toward Sol Duc Resort 3 miles up trail, and to the left, the trail leads to Deer Lake 3 miles ahead.

data.title: [Sign] Era of Elegance Wayside #133a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

data.bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
data.audioDescription: Era of Elegance Wayside. 3 minutes This three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel stands in a grassy area to the right of the Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort entrance. An old black and white photograph of a large four-story hotel and adjacent buildings fills the panel. The photo shows one side and the front of the building. The windows on the top floor are encased in dormers that protrude off the roof, five on the front of the building and two on the side. The third and second floors each have twelve windows flush to the building across the front and six windows on the side. The first floor is wrapped in a covered porch with large windows spanning each side. In the distance, in line with the hotel, are smaller buildings. In front of the hotel is a manicured lawn with a few bushes and trees. Text across the top reads: Era of Elegance. Excitement and bustle fill the air as passengers board a steamship on a misty Seattle morning in 1912. They cruise seventy-five miles to Port Crescent, shuttle twenty miles by auto stages, ferry across Lake Crescent on the steamboat Betty Earles, and travel the final fourteen miles via Stanley Steamers to celebrated Sol Duc Hot Springs Hotel. Michael Earles built the original hotel on this site between 1910 and 1912. He was convinced the hot mineral waters offered cures for rheumatism, liver diseases, alcoholism and other disorders. Rustic yet elegant, the 165-room hotel sported a large veranda encircling three sides. The nearby sanitorium featured a medical staff, operating room and sun parlor. As many as 10,000 guests each summer sipped mineral waters and soaked in hot baths. Horseback riding, tennis, croquet, bowling and dancing ensured a full agenda. After only four years of grandeur, sparks from a defective flue set the cedar roof afire. Within a few hours much of this magnificent resort had burned to the ground. On the left below the text are two old color advertisements for the Sol Duc. Each ad shows massive snow-covered mountains rising up behind the red roofed hotel with its large green front lawn where people are walking. A banner across the bottom of the ad on the left reads, Magnificent Hotel and Playground, and across the ad on the right, Baths and Sanitorium. Below the ads is a quote from Chicago, Milwaukee and Puget Sound Company, circa 1912 that reads: The mail lobby, capacious and ornate, with massive columns running through the center greets the eye of the guest while near the front entrance is a great fireplace, lending an air of comfort and cheeriness.

data.title: Sol Duc Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop B

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

data.bodyText: Campground registration and restroom for Sol Duc Campground Loop B
data.audioDescription: Sol Duc Campground Registration Loop B. 2 minutes At the edge of the roadway in front of the restroom is a roof-covered 2-sided bulletin board with information about the campground and park. On the front, attached on the left side, is the campground registration board, a vertical framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. A brown lidded box holding campground registration envelopes is to the left of the board. Standing alone to the left is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is the slot for slipping in the envelope. A green and white sign attached to the left leg of the bulletin board frame reads, All pets must be on a leash. Clean up after your pet. Posted notices provide information about campground regulations, pet regulations, firewood, bear warnings, and wildlife, food, and your safety. A map of the Sol Duc area is also posted here. On the back side of the bulletin board is information about wilderness regulations, backcountry safety, bear awareness, cougars, and park preservation. Emergency information is provided. Contact a ranger or dial 911 in an emergency. Other notices include no fireworks, day hikes at Sol Duc, fee checklist, and fishing regulations. Behind the bulletin board and up a slight rise is a rectangular restroom building with entrance doors on each side. A dirt path leads to the women’s room on the left and a dirt path leads to the men’s room on the right.

data.title: Sol Duc RV Dump Station

images.altText: A black and white symbol of an RV dumping waste.

data.bodyText: Dump station for Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort RV Park
data.audioDescription: Sol Duc RV Dump Station. 30 seconds A brown and white sign attached to a post reads, RV Septic Dump Station. $10 per use. $5 with Interagency Senior or Access Pass. Not included in camping fee. Attached below this sign is a white paper sign with black typed text that reads, Please pay dump fee at Eagle Ranger Station. To the left of the signs is a water hose and a concrete pad with a drain where RV sewage is dumped.

data.title: Slough Trailhead at Mora Ranger Station
data.listingDescription: A fairly level, 0.9 mile (1.4 km) forested trail to the Quillayute River.

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

data.bodyText: A fairly level, 0.9 mile (1.4 km) forested trail to the Quillayute River.
data.audioDescription: Slough Trailhead. 30 seconds To the right of the trailhead is a small brown and white wooden sign attached horizontally to a post that reads, Slough Trail. Attached to the post is a no dogs permitted sign. The trail, here, is narrow and almost immediately enters the forest.

data.title: Sol Duc Amphitheater

images.altText: Black and white symbol for amphitheater with the figure of a person at the front and bench seating facing them.

data.bodyText: Amphitheater at Sol Duc Campground
data.audioDescription: Sol Duc Amphitheater. 1 minute A flat, dirt path from the parking area to the amphitheater passes through a mixed forest of pine and deciduous trees. Green moss hangs from tree branches and low growing plants carpet the forest floor. The approach to the amphitheater is from the rear where on a downward sloping surface, are nine rows of wooden bench seats, separated into three sections by aisles. In front of these benches are three more rows of benches with no aisles. At the bottom of the slope facing the benches, a grey wooden building with a flat roof and a vertical row of enclosed speakers on the right, sits atop a two-foot-high concrete stage. The center of the building is recessed toward the back with doors that open to reveal a projection screen. The projection booth is in the back of the amphitheater at the top of the slope. To the right of the stage on the ground, is a round, stone edged fire ring and a semicircular bench.

data.title: LBJ Ranch Taxiway

images.altText: A long stretch of asphalt extends out to the horizon. White parking lines line the right edge.
images.title: The LBJ Ranch Taxiway
images.caption: The historic taxiway now provides parking for visitors coming to the LBJ Ranch.

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

data.bodyText: Shortly after acquiring the ranch from his aunt, Frank Martin, in 1951, Lyndon Johnson set out to improve access to the property by adding a 3,000-foot grass landing strip. By the time Johnson became president in 1963, a series of improvements resulted in a 6,300-foot asphalt airstrip and connected taxiway. Since 2008, the taxiway has served as an integral part of the driving loop through the LBJ Ranch and a parking area for the nearby Airplane Hangar visitor center.
data.audioDescription: A 1000 foot strip of asphalt stretches east to west between two fenced pastures. It is approximately 40 feet wide. One side of the asphalt has white lines denoting parking spaces. Four of those spaces are also marked with blue and white wheelchair accessible icons.

data.title: Riverside Viewpoint
data.listingDescription: Two interpretive panels discussing the elements of slavery within the Eppes’ family farms, with a view of the confluence of the James and Appomattox Rivers.

images.altText: view with blue sky, river beneath, and green grass in the foreground and two signs on the right side
images.title: Riverside Viewpoint
images.caption: Two interpretive panels at the viewpoint of the confluence.

data.bodyText: From this viewpoint, visitors can see the confluence of the Appomattox River from the west and the James River to the east and north.
data.audioDescription: A wooden fence of stacked logs is between the cliff and yourself. The view beyond the short, grassy cliff, is off the Appomattox River to the left, and the James River to the right and straight ahead. The rivers are wide and on the other side, the land is covered in trees with a few small buildings to see. There are two interpretive waysides next to each other, both waysides have a black band on top, with the National Park Service arrowhead in the top right corner. The text is all in black and the background of both panels is a light tan color. The panel on the left reads, “Resistance and Punishments. Prior to the Civil War, Dr. Eppes commanded his sales to not get drunk, steal, commit adultery, damage property, nor attack him, the overseers, or each other. The enslaved people resisted by stealing, feigning illness, breaking tools, and at least one slave fought an overseer. In an attempt to make his laborers follow the rules, Eppes commonly took away his slaves’ ability to leave the plantation or he decreased their food allotment. He and his overseers whipped those who resisted and had slaves whip each other as punishment for fighting or stealing from one another. Eppes sold a man named Bins in 1859 for his continued resistance. Though none of the slaves here tried to escape before the war, between May and August of 1862, 106 of Eppes’ 122 slaves escaped. Of the escaped slaves, at least four served in the Federal Navy during the war and at least two others served in United States Colored Troop regiments by war’s end.” On the left under the text is a photo of an enslaved person looking away from the camera, with multiple whipping scares on their back. Underneath the text in the middle is a quote in bold letters that states, “Patience and Dilsy received a few blows for laziness, by Richard Eppes on June 18, 1858”. The last photo on the right is a drawing of an enslaver whipping an enslaved woman who is tied with her hands up on a pole. The caption reads “From a slave narrative published in 1858”. The panel on the right is titled “Beyond the Big House”. “By 1860, Richard Eppes owned 2,300 acres divided into four farms on all sides of the confluence of these two rivers and held 113 people as slaves ranging in age from a few months old to 79 years old. He hired two men as overseers and one free black man before the Civil War. Enslaved field hands planted, tended, and harvested wheat, corn, and oats; they also fished, slaughtered livestock, picked fruit, and did other jobs that generated income for the Eppes family. Eppes’ skilled enslaved men worked as carpenters, blacksmiths, and sawyers. One enslaved woman was a weaver, and another was a midwife. The enslaved community worked on Eppes’ Bermuda Hundred farm (across the Appomattox River where the factory is), on Eppes’ Island to the east (across the James River), and south of here at the Appomattox and Hopewell farms. Only the island remains undeveloped today”. To the write of the text is a drawing of a map showing the different farms of the Eppes’ family as was described in the text. Beneath the text is a drawing of enslaved people stacking wheat and using ox to pull flat wagons. It is titled “Culpeper, VA, Stacking wheat by Edwin Forbes (LOC)”.

data.title: C&O Canal Lock 18

images.altText: People walk along the towpath next to a stone made lock.
images.title: Lock 18
images.caption: Lock 18

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.
data.audioDescription: (117 words) Lock 18 is located along the towpath in Potomac, MD. From the Great Falls Tavern Visitor Center parking lot, follow the sidewalks to the visitor center, passing the concessions building on your right and the public restrooms building on your left. At the visitor center building, turn right, walk about 25 feet and cross the wooden pedestrian bridge over Lock 20. Turn left and walk 3/10 of a mile on the towpath. The lock sits in the ground parallel to the towpath. Two stone walls create the lock chamber, which is filled with water. The chamber is approximately 90 feet long. Stone ruins of an old lockhouse remain across the canal from the towpath. End of Description.

data.title: C&O Canal Lock 23 (Violettes Lock)

images.altText: The towpath wonders toward a two chamber lock, one chamber on the right the other on the left.
images.title: Lock 23
images.caption: Lock 23

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  
 
Lock 23 is also known as Violettes Lock.
data.audioDescription: (90 words) Lock 23 is located along the towpath near Potomac, MD. It can be accessed from a small parking lot located at the end of Violettes Lock Road. The lock sits next to the dirt parking lot. A vehicle access bridge crosses the lock, with railings along both sides. The dirt towpath is across the lock bridge, with south being to the left and north being to the right. Taking the towpath to the left, approximately 20 feet ahead, you will cross another bridge over Inlet Lock #2. End of Description.

data.title: Appomattox Plantation Driveway
data.listingDescription: The entrance gates to the Eppes' family home, the home was a century old by the time U.S. forces occupied the site in 1864.

images.altText: Historic, black and white photo of driveway entrance gate with two stone pillars and iron gate.
images.title: Driveway Entrance Gates Appomattox Manor
images.caption: Historic photo of the entrance gates to the Eppes' family home taken in the 1980s.

data.bodyText: The Eppes' family home was a century old by the time U.S. forces occupied the site in 1864, known as Appomattox Manor in the Appomattox Plantation. This driveway was created in the 1841 as people began to approach by carriage and no longer from the river.
data.audioDescription: A dirt and gravel covered road leads through two stone pillars wide enough for a vehicle to enter through. The stone pillars have large iron lamps on top with a two-door iron swing-gate at the entrance. To the left and right of the stone pillars is iron fencing. The dirt and gravel road is flat and leads straight towards the Eppes' family home, and travels between two large trees.

data.title: City Point Historical Highway Markers
data.listingDescription: Historical Highway Markers for Appomattox Manor, General Grant’s Headquarters, and City Point.
data.bodyText:
Three historical highway markers were placed in 1961 by the Virginia Department of Historic Resources through the Virginia historical highway marker program.

TEXT ON SIGN: City Point. First settled as Bermuda Cittie by Sir Thomas Dale 1613. Important colonial port. Peter Francisco put ashore 1765 was Washington's "One Man Army." Incorporated 1826. Annexed Hopewell 1923.

TEXT ON SIGN: Appomattox Manor. Patented 1635 by Captain Francis Epes. Who came by tradition in the Hopewell. Owned by same family probably longer than nay land in U.S. Shelled by British during American Revolution.

TEXT ON SIGN: General Grant's Headquarters at Appomattox Manor 1864-65 during siege of Petersburg and Richmond. President Lincoln spent 3 weeks in City Point during April, 1865.
data.audioDescription: Three large signs set six feet apart. Each sign is about three feet by three feet with a black border and white background. The letters are black and stick out from the background. TEXT ON SIGN: City Point. First settled as Bermuda Cittie by Sir Thomas Dale 1613. Important colonial port. Peter Francisco put ashore 1765 was Washington's "One Man Army." Incorporated 1826. Annexed Hopewell 1923. TEXT ON SIGN: Appomattox Manor. Patented 1635 by Captain Francis Epes. Who came by tradition in the Hopewell. Owned by same family probably longer than nay land in U.S. Shelled by British during American Revolution. TEXT ON SIGN: General Grant's Headquarters at Appomattox Manor 1864-65 during siege of Petersburg and Richmond. President Lincoln spent 3 weeks in City Point during April, 1865.

data.title: Ethno-botanical Garden
data.listingDescription: This one-acre garden of native plants restores a site that had been overtaken by invasive plants near the Rainy Lake Visitor Center.

images.altText: A path of crushed rock with plants on either side.
images.title: Ethno-Botanical Garden
images.caption: Ethno-Botanical Garden

data.bodyText:
This one-acre garden of native plants restores a site that had been overtaken by invasive plants. In the 1990s, during dredging for the boat basin, invasive reed canary grass was transported to this location. Due to this plant’s prolific roots and early growing season, reed canary grass stole resources from vulnerable native plants, transforming this once bountiful site into a barren field. The term ‘ethno-botanical' refers to the cultural importance and use of these plants to Ojibwe people.  

Our lives depend on the environment in which we live. Each of us is affected by nature's rhythm whether it’s the availability of seasonal foods, changes in outdoor recreation, or the clothes we wear. For the Ojibwe people, each season brought different plants used for food, medicine, ceremonies, and raw materials. 

Garden tours, interpretative signage, and exhibits along the scenic ADA accessible trail share the history of local Ojibwe and the plants on which they relied. It also reminds us of the significance native plants have in our daily lives.

data.title: General Grant's Cabin At City Point

images.altText: Historic photo from 1864 of men sitting in chairs outside under trees with white tents behind.
images.title: Grant and staff tents at City Point VA
images.caption: Historic photo of General Grants, and staff, tents in the summer of 1864 at City Point.

data.bodyText: On June 15, 1864, Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant arrived at City Point to conduct military operations against Petersburg. Grant chose the Eppes family Appomattox Plantation at City Point for his headquarters and supply depot because of its strategic location. It provided easy water communication with Fort Monroe and Washington D.C. Supplies could be sent up the James River directly to City Point. From here the old City Point Railroad ran from the waterfront to the rear of the United States Army at Petersburg, allowing Grant to easily send reinforcements and supplies to the field.
data.audioDescription: General Grant's cabin is a wooden cabin with the planks constructed together while placed vertically. It is shaped like a wide "T", with the front door on one side. This door is currently covered with plexiglass. There are windows on each side of the building with a fireplace in the back. The chimney is made of red bricks. The interpretive panel in the grass to the front states the following. "From November 1864 through March 1865, Lt. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant lived in this modest cabin. From here he directed Union armies in the climactic final campaigns of the war and hosted some of the notable figures of the era: President and Mrs. Lincoln, Major General William T. Sherman, Secretary of State William Seward, and Secretary of War Edwin Stanton. This was one of 22 cabins that stood on the Eppes property. After the war, Grant's cabin was moved to Philadelphia, where it remained on display for 116 years. In 1981, the National Park Service returned the cabin to City Point and reassembled it on its original site. About 10 percent of the structure is original. It is one of the few vestiges of the Union occupations of City Point." The background of the panel is tan, with a sepia photo of eight wooden cabins in a row leading up the Eppes family front door. It is captioned, "Grant's cabin is at the left of this photograph. The cabin was built in November 1864 to replace the tents that had served as headquarters during warmer months". To the right of the photo is another black and white photo of three men standing in front of the cabin dressed in uniform. It is captioned, "Grant and some of his staff officers pose on the porch of the cabin. Grant is in the center".

data.title: C&O Canal Lock 69

images.altText: Looking down a water filled lock with two parallel stone walls on the right and left.
images.title: Lock 69
images.caption: Lock 69

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 69, also known as Twigg’s Lock, was completed in late 1849 to early 1850. It is the 11th of the upper 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. However, the use of wood created many problems. The wood lining in many of these locks were replaced by concrete from 1891–1924. A stop gate was placed on the upstream end of the lock to keep water in the canal as part of the Battie Mixon fishing area. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

The name of the lock comes from the family that used to serve as locktenders. No remnants of the lockhouse remain. 

Locks 69-71 are considered as the Oldtown Locks. This watered section of the canal is part of the Battie Mixon fishing area.
data.audioDescription: (387 words) Lock 69 is located in Oldtown, MD. To access it, go to the parking lot off of Green Spring Road SE. The parking lot is laid out as a circle, but the parking spots don’t start until about 100 feet in from the turn off from Green Spring Road. In the first row of parking spots, on the side closest to the parking entrance within the circle, is a park bulletin board. Just to the left, is a little dirt walkway with a slight incline that veers to the left. This little 20-foot path leads to a grassy area along a watered section of the canal. Once on flat surface, walk about 20 feet forward and the canal will be about 30 feet away from your right. About 50 feet straight ahead is Lock 70. There is a small, 15-foot wooden bridge that crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Once across the bridge, walk about 5 more feet to get to the gravel towpath. Turn left to head downstream. About 70 feet ahead are gates blocking vehicles from entering the towpath from Green Spring Road with enough space for pedestrians and cyclist to pass through. After walking past these, about 10 feet away is Green Spring Road. Once you cross the road, there will be another set of gates blocking vehicles from entering the towpath. Go straight through and head down about a quarter of a mile. On the left, about 5 feet from the towpath, is the lock, which runs parallel to the towpath. It is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, treated wood, and concrete make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the downstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you in a 15-foot wide grassy area between the lock and a bypass flume. The bypass flume runs from a basin above the lock and discharges through a sloping wall. A stop gate was placed on the upstream end of the lock to keep water in the canal. No remnants of the lockhouse remain. End of description.

data.title: Appomattox Manor Carriage Front
data.listingDescription: The east wing of the Eppes family home was added in 1841 and added a parlor, sitting room, three bedrooms on the second floor, and an entry hall making it the “front” of the house.

images.altText: Historic, black and white photo of east side of home, with large group of people on front steps
images.title: Appomattox Manor May 1865
images.caption: Rufus Ingalls and party sitting on front steps of Eppes family home in May 1865.

data.bodyText: The east wing of the Eppes family home was added in 1841 and added a parlor, sitting room, three bedrooms on the second floor, and an entry hall making it the “front” of the house. By the 1850s a formal driveway had been created taking advantage of a new maintained county road that pushed a shift to land-based transportation.
data.audioDescription: The eastern addition of the Epps family home has a wrap-around porch with gray wood flooring and white pillars placed about six feet apart. There are six steps leading up to the porch and an oversized wooden door to the entrance. To the right and left of the doorway are two large windows. The house is white-sided and the roof is red-bricked. There are three regular-sized windows on the second story, jutting out from the angle of the roof. In front of the home is a dirt and gravel driveway that creates a circle, and then leads to the left/south.

data.title: Appomattox Manor Riverside
data.listingDescription: The original front of the Eppes family home built in the 1760s, also known as Appomattox Manor, faced the rivers as most visitors came by boat.

images.altText: Historic, black and white photo of white house with red roof, overgrown bushes in front of house
images.title: Appomattox Manor Summer 1864
images.caption: Historic photo of the Eppes family home from the summer of 1864

data.bodyText: The Appomattox Manor, the Eppes family home, was constructed in the 1760s (the middle portion of the house that we see today). Directionally built to face the river, the Eppes family took advantage of the better light and airflow through this southern exposure. As the family grew throughout time, so did the family home.
data.audioDescription: Standing on your left is a wooden rose arbor; built by the Eppes family after the Civil War. About 20 yards in front of you is the Eppes family two-story home. It is a white-sided house with a red-brown colored roof, and there are four red-bricked chimneys; the house is structured like a "U" opening up towards the rose arbor. The middle portion of the house has one wooden door and three large windows. The top floor has normal-sized windows jutted out from the angle of the roof. Along the front of the house is a covered porch that begins in the middle section of the home. This porch has a gray-wooden floor and white pillars that lead to the roof; it continues to the left of the house and around to the other side. The left side of the home has multiple large windows on the lower level and two normal-sized windows jutted out for the angle of the roof on the second level. The right side of the home has a few large windows on the lower level and, two normal-sized windows jutted out for the angle of the roof on the second level. In front of the right side of the home is a medium-sized rhododendron bush.

data.title: Appomattox Plantation Dependencies

images.altText: White two-story building with red roof and two red chimneys, tree in foreground of image.
images.title: Kitchen and Laundry Dependencies
images.caption: The kitchen and laundry dependency for the enslaved workers of the Eppes family home.

data.bodyText: Built-in the early 1800s, these small buildings were critical to the plantation’s operation. The kitchen and laundry were separate from the main home to reinforce the relationship between enslaved people and the Eppes family. The food being prepared here came from the plantation and the nearby rivers. Here enslaved women kept the fire going, prepared meals for the Eppes family and for the enslaved population at Appomattox Plantation. In the laundry room, enslaved women worked to wash napkins, linens, and clothing by hand.
data.audioDescription: The laundry and kitchen dependency is a two-story building with two rooms on the lower level and upper level. On the side facing the Eppes family home, there are two doors near the center of the building. The doorway on the left leads to the kitchen, the doorway on the right leads to the laundry area. Both sides of the building have a chimney. The building is white-sided with a red slanted roof and two windows on each side of the doorways.

data.title: C&O Canal Lock 46

images.altText: A foot bridge spans the top of a lock with a white lockhouse in the background.
images.title: Lock 46
images.caption: Lock 46

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.
data.audioDescription: (107) Lock 46 is located on the towpath in Clear Spring, Maryland. From the Lock 46 parking lot, continue down the gravel road for about 180 feet where it merges into the towpath. Turn left, east, onto the towpath. After 10 feet the lock is parallel to the towpath on the right. The lock walls are made of stone blocks. The two walls create the lock chamber that is about ten feet deep. The upstream and downstream entrance gates are missing. Just past the lock is the Potomac River. Walk another 30 feet and a stone arch is on your right and the lockhouse is on your left.

data.title: Starting Point for City Point Audio Tour
data.listingDescription: The entrance to the parking area at City Point.

images.altText: Large, paved parking lot, with brown metal gate, and brown entrance sign. White car parked near sign
images.title: Parking lot for City Point
images.caption: The entrance to the parking area at City Point.

data.bodyText: Sir Thomas Dale established city Point in 1613. City Point was a town in Prince George County, Virginia, the city of Hopewell annexed in 1923. It became part of Petersburg National Battlefield in 1979. Walk around City Point to explore why this area was, and still is, a popular place for living along the rivers. The Eppes family established the Appomattox plantation and their home here as early as 1635, until 1976. In 1864, General Grant and the U.S. Army used City Point as its headquarters to supply the army during the Petersburg Campaign.
data.audioDescription: The large, paved parking lot has a wooden fence close to the road, with a large brown metal gate at the entrance. A large brown sign marks the parking lot, with a green section along the top portion. Text on Sign: National Park Service. U.S. Department of Interior. General Grant's Headquarters at City Point. Petersburg National Battlefield.

data.title: The Memorial House Museum
data.listingDescription: Learn about the decade-long effort to build a Memorial House to honor George Washington at his birthplace.

images.altText: brick two story house with dormers
images.title: The Memorial House Museum
images.caption: Memorial House Museum

data.bodyText:
In June of 1923, a group of public-spirited women met in the home of wealthy socialite Josephine Wheelwright Rust, a descendant of the Washington Family, to discuss plans to develop George Washington's birthplace for the anniversary of his 200th birthday in 1932. During this meeting, the Wakefield National Memorial Association (WNMA) was born and Rust became the group's president. As president, Rust's vision was to build from scratch a "Memorial House" at the place of Washington's birth and surround it with the appearances of an 18th century plantation environment. This romantic, but unrealistic vision would create a series of challenges to the entire development of the Historic Area and the Memorial House Museum.

Rust initiated her plan by approaching Congress for funding to build the house. Congress agreed to the request and sent instructions to build a house as close as possible to the originial design. With no surviving images of Washington's birthhouse to use as inspiration, it is rumored that Rust decided to base the house on the architecture of local colonial structures that she had known growing up, including her childhood home, Twiford, still located in Westmoreland County today. Rust's "Memorial House" would not resemble the birthhouse of George Washington as it would be much larger and grander than the 1732 home. 

Rust was determined to place the Memorial House at the same location of the monument the War Department had placed in 1896. Although the monument stood on grounds that were reputedly the location of the birthhouse, there were many who doubted that it was the actual location. Moving the monument was also costly, and seemed to some to be a frivolous expense, considering the nation was in the midst of the Great Depression. Nonetheless, Rust perservered. The funds to move the monument arrived, and it was removed from its existing base, loaded on carts in pieces, and installed on a new base at the entrance to the park. 

With the arrival of the National Park Service (NPS), who arrived after the creation of George Washington Birthplace National Monument in January 1930, Rust found challenges with her ideas for not only the Memorial House, but the Colonial Revival Garden, and the buildings and layout of the Historic Area. 

Rust's plans for the Memorial House Museum went forward, and the house was completed in the summer of 1931, in time for the Bicentennial of Washington's birth. On June 26, 1931, Rust died, only four days after turning over the deed for the property to the National Park Service. A tribute service was held for her on February 11, 1932, in the Memorial House Museum with many WNMA members in attendance. On May 14, 1932, the Memorial House Museum was officially opened by the National Park Service.

images.altText: Young women and girls wrapped in red and black robes, decorated with designs of salmon, butterflies, and thunderbirds. A young child in a woven hat plays a drum.
images.caption: Members of the Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe at a ceremony at the site of the Elwha Dam in September 2011. NPS Photo.

data.bodyText: Artistic and cultural exhibits at the heritage center explore the Elwha River restoration and č̕ixʷícən village artifacts. (The name of the village site, č̕ixʷícən, which means inner harbor.) The building is also used for trainings, gatherings, and tribal offices. Learn more here.
data.audioDescription: Elwha Klallam Heritage Center. 3 minutes The tan concrete building has a tall, central section with an asymmetrical curved roof and two lower curved wings to each side, a bank of windows across the left wing and no windows across the right wing. The front door is in the center section and is flanked on each side by large windows. Above the door and windows, four evenly spaced thick logs jut straight out from the front wall each coming to rest atop a tall, square wooden vertical column anchored to the concrete patio in front of the building. The front cut of each log is adorned with a round, orange, metal face design, each having a different facial expression. Laid horizontally across the top of the logs are three horizontal timbers upon which sits a carved, wooden canoe painted in traditional black artistic designs. Attached to the front of the two center columns are tan colored animal designs carved from wood. On the right side of the patio is a red square wooden structure with a wide peaked roof that frames the Heritage Center sign attached in the center. The front edge of the roof is adorned with black half-moons. On the top horizonal framing board are the words, Strong People. The Heritage Center sign has a black background edged with two red lines. At the top, words in yellow read, Elwha Klallam. At the bottom, Heritage Center. In the center is a white, circular tribal seal outlined in black and red with three thick horizontal red lines on each side. The top lines have three half-moon designs, the second line, two half-moons, and the bottom line, one half-moon. Curving along the inside top of the seal are the words, Elwha Klallam Tribe, in black. In the center, a red, black, and white thunderbird design shows a bird with open wings, it’s head and large beak facing left, and yellow lightning bolts crisscrossed behind it. Below the bird on the left and the right facing each other are killer whales, designed in red, black and yellow. Along the bottom horizontal framing board is black text in the Elwha Klallam language.

data.listingDescription: Fee Station, Currently closed for road construction

data.audioDescription: Elwha River Entrance Station. 1 minute On the left side of the single lane road at the entrance to the parking area is a small brown building with windows on four sides and a sign in the front listing park fees. A paved path off the parking lot leads to two side-by-side restrooms. The one on the right facing the path is a wheelchair accessible, all gender, single stall restroom building with a vault toilet. The entrance door is on the right front of the building. The smaller all gender, single stall vault toilet restroom on the left is not wheelchair accessible. The door is on the left side. On the opposite side of the parking area from the restrooms is a bulletin board with information about trails in the area, stock use, trail etiquette, and backcountry safety. A notice provides information about the fishing closure for the Elwha River and all its tributaries and another notice states what to do in an emergency. Contact a ranger or dial 911.

data.title: Hurricane Hill Trailhead
data.listingDescription: One of the most popular day hikes is the Hurricane Hill trail, about 3 miles (4.8 km) round trip and climbing 700 feet (213 meters) to a high point with 360-degree views in clear weather. The trailhead is at the end of the road, just 1.3 miles (2.1 km) past the Hurricane Ridge Visitor Center. Overflow parking is available at Picnic Area B.

images.altText: A group of three hikers, with large misty mountainsides rising beyond.
images.caption: Photo by C. Bubar/NPS

data.bodyText: One of the most popular day hikes is the Hurricane Hill trail, about 3 miles (4.8 km) round trip and climbing 700 feet (213 meters) to a high point with 360-degree views in clear weather. The trailhead is at the end of the road, just 1.3 miles (2.1 km) past the Hurricane Ridge Visitor Center. Overflow parking is available at Picnic Area B.
data.audioDescription: Hurricane Hill Trailhead. 2 minutes Parking at the trailhead is along the right side of the road. The trail is across the road on the left. At the trailhead on the right is a wooden bulletin board where park information is posted. An interpretive panel is attached to the board on the left. Filling the top of the panel is a map of the trail with the text, You Are Here, noted toward the bottom. Text below the map reads, Hurricane Hill Trail. The 1.6-mile trail to Hurricane Hill ascends gradually at first, then climbs more steeply through subalpine meadows. From the top there are views of the Olympic Mountains to the south and Vancouver Island, British Columbia to the north. Average hiking time to top is one and one-half hours. Elevation gain is 650 feet. Text continues: Window on the Wilderness. On this hike you can get a taste of Wilderness without packing deep into backcountry. No roads slice the interior. Except for the trail, there are few signs of human impact. To the left of the text is a black and white illustration of a robust black bear in profile facing right. Trees grow in the background. On the right side of the bulletin board are posted park notices and regulations. About 20 feet up trail, a two-foot-tall log post stands in the center of the trail. To its right is a sign on a taller post that reads: No pets, weapons, or vehicles.

data.title: Madison Falls

images.altText: A waterfall cascades into a small pool.
images.caption: Madison Falls. Photo by J. Burger/NPS.

data.bodyText: Madison Falls
data.audioDescription: Madison Falls. 1 minute The smooth, wheelchair accessible trail leads to an area that overlooks the falls. Here, there is a four-foot-tall fence on the left side of the trail and a bench for seating. The water of Madison Falls cascades down a steep, rocky wall covered with bright green moss, all framed by the surrounding lush, green forest. At the bottom, the long white ribbon of water ends in a clear, deep pool which is part of the creek that flows in front of the viewing area. The creek is strewn with rocks, gravel and parts of downed tree trunks and branches.

data.title: Morse Creek Overlook

images.altText: A mountain view from an overlook.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

data.bodyText: Pause to enjoy the view, and learn from an interpretive wayside about Ancient Lake Morse.
data.audioDescription: Ancient Lake Morse Wayside / Overlook. 2 minutes This three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel stands in front of a three-foot-high stone wall overlooking a gorge carved into a mountain landscape. Text at the top of the panel reads: Ancient Lake Morse. Thousands of years ago, a great ice sheet from Canada flowed south through the Puget Sound and west through the Strait of Juan de Fuca. The ice sheet abutted alpine glaciers flowing from the Olympic Mountains. As warming occurred, meltwater from mountain glaciers was dammed by the ice sheet, forming ancient Lake Morse. Continued warming caused the ice sheet to withdraw, draining the lake. Morse Creek now parallels the road. In ancient times it flowed over a ridge of soft sediments connecting Blue and Round Mountains. When glaciers dammed the creek, it was diverted to a new path between Round Mountain and the present road, cutting through hard lava rocks. The resulting gorge is visible as you drive down the road or from the short trail at the Tunnels parking area. Below the text are two side-by-side images that compare the ancient landscape to present time. On the left, a color drawing depicts a past landscape. In the foreground, a green hill with scattered tall, dark pine trees, slopes into the expansive blue waters of Ancient Lake Morse. The lake extends into the distance cutting between the peaks of Round Mountain on the left and Blue Mountain on the right. The image on the right is a black and white photograph of the present-day landscape. Where the lake once existed is now a deep winding gorge filled with dense pine forests. Without the lake, the full height of Round Mountain and Blue Mountain is exposed.

data.title: Mouth of the Elwha Beach

images.altText: A surfer carries a surfboard toward the beach under dramatic, cloudy skies.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

data.bodyText: The restoring Elwha nearshore. This is private property and a very fragile environment. Please be respectful.
data.audioDescription: Elwha Nearshore Trailhead. 3 minutes A large panel with color photographs and text provides information about this area. A text header reads: Welcome to the restoring Elwha nearshore. This is private property and a very fragile environment. Please be respectful. In the center of the panel text reads: This nearshore ecosystem is federally designated critical habitat utilized by several federal and state listed species. The Elwha nearshore serves as nursery grounds for migrating salmon as well as migrating and spawning grounds for surf smelt, sand lance and other forage fish. Beach features including vegetation and driftwood stabilize the beach and provide shade and habitat for a variety of species. What can you do. Leave Vegetation and Log Line (Large Woody Debris) untouched. No Driftwood Collection, Cutting, or Burning. No Unauthorized Motor Vehicles. This is a walking beach. No Fires or Fireworks. No Camping. No Firearms. No Alcohol. Leave No Trace Color photographs ring the text. Beginning in the top left corner and moving clockwise, a large flock of white birds, some floating on the water, some hovering overhead with extended wings. A caption reads, Gulls and eagles feeding on federally listed forage fish eulachon. Next, a juvenile Surf Smelt in profile facing left. It has a long thin body with a dark round eye, dark scales on top and silver scales on its side, a side fin, a fin on its top, and a V-shaped tail fin. On the far right, a magnified view of many round white objects and grains of sand. The caption reads, Forage fish eggs laid on upper intertidal beaches. Below, a silver-blue fish with a dark round eye atop a ruler that measures the fish at five-inches. The caption reads, Longfin smelt. In the bottom right corner, a high aerial view captioned, Elwha River mouth, shows the path of the main river channel through a forested area and then out across the white sand beach where the main channel and vein like tributaries enter the ocean. To the left, an eight-inch silver fish with grey vertical stripes and a dark round eye laying atop a ruler. The caption reads, Juvenile Chum, Chinook, and Coho salmon. The final photograph is an aerial view of a beach with a jumble of light-colored wood. The caption reads, Driftwood log line along beach.

data.title: Mouth of the Elwha Beach Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This sandy beach on the Strait of Juan de Fuca was formed after the dams on the Elwha River were removed in 2011 and 2014, gradually releasing many tons of sediment. It's a great place to appreciate the free flowing Elwha River's journey, not to mention catch a beautiful sunset. Look for geese and beavers in the nearby wetland, eagles and gulls fishing in the river, and seals offshore!Though not part of Olympic National Park, the mouth of the Elwha is a wonderful place to see

images.altText: A shore with sun breaking through after a rain shower.
images.caption: The Strait of Juan de Fuca after a rain shower, seen from the mouth of the Elwha River. Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

data.bodyText:
This sandy beach on the Strait of Juan de Fuca was formed after the dams on the Elwha River were removed in 2011 and 2014, gradually releasing many tons of sediment. It's a great place to appreciate the free flowing Elwha River's journey, not to mention catch a beautiful sunset. Look for geese and beavers in the nearby wetland, eagles and gulls fishing in the river, and seals offshore!

Though not part of Olympic National Park, the mouth of the Elwha is a wonderful place to see how the Elwha River has transformed in the years since dam removal.
data.audioDescription: West Elwha Beach Trailhead. 1 minute A yellow gate with a sign that reads, Fire Lane, Do Not Block, spans most of the entrance to this trailhead. Access to the trail is at the left side of the gate. The trail is flat with a gravel surface. A tall brown and white sign on the right side of the trail reads: West Elwha Beach. Help keep it clean. Public access on the dike and beach is provided by private landowners and the Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe. Continued use depends on your compliance with the following: Disposal bins at the portable toilets. Protect birds and wildlife. Pack it in – pack it out. Symbols on the sign include: Clean up after your dog. Dogs must be on a leash Hiking, swimming, surfing and wildlife watching are permitted. Firearms, fires, camping, fireworks, and drones are not permitted Text at the bottom of the sign reads: This beach is maintained by community members and volunteers led by the Surfrider Foundation and Clallam County Marine Resources Committee and in Partnership with Clallam County.

data.title: North Peninsula Overlook
data.listingDescription: On a clear day, look out at across the valley to the Strait of Juan de Fuca.

images.altText: A wayside sign near an overlook view of a valley/
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

data.bodyText: On a clear day, look out at across the valley to the Strait of Juan de Fuca.
data.audioDescription: Hurricane Ridge Road Wayside Overlook. 4 minutes Along the front edge of the parking lot is a flat, gravel overlook area completely outlined by a six-inch-high concrete bumper. The landscape beyond the overlook begins with low tree covered hills and open areas with structures, then a wide expanse of water, with mountains in the distance on the opposite shore. On the left side of the gravel area are three wayside panels, each in a three-foot-tall, angled metal frame. The wayside on the extreme left is titled, Siege of Ice. Text reads: Only ice, sky, and a few jagged islands of rock – an ocean of ice filled the horizon. If there is valley fog, imagine it is ice, and you will have a picture of the continental glacier, grinding against the terrain. Glaciers were the prime architects of the scenery before you. But in this green landscape the only way to comprehend the extent of the ice is to examine the aftermath. A thousand feet above this spot the melting glacier dumped tons of rock and gravel debris. Only glaciers could have carved this valley’s steep walls. Filling the left side of the panel, a black and white drawing shows dark finger-like edges of mountains in a white landscape. A smaller image beneath the text shows three large rocks on white ground with a dark hill in the background. The caption reads: House-sized boulders lie scattered around the park, their crystals foreign to Olympic rock. Moving to the right, the next wayside is titled, Oh say can you see? Filling the top of this wide panel is an illustration of the landscape before you with various points of interest labeled and the Strait of Juan de Fuca in the center. From left to right, Victoria, Canada, Mt. Douglas, Haro Strait, Discovery Island, San Juan Islands, American Camp, San Juan Island National Historic Park, Bellingham Washington, Dungeness National Wildlife Refuge, Mt. Baker 10,778 feet, Sequim, Washington, Protection Island, North Cascades National Park, Puget Sound, and Glacier Peak. Text below reads: In clear weather you can see Canada and the volcanic peaks of the Cascade Mountains. Visibility here is becoming increasingly impaired, however, by pollutants from sources including industry, wood stoves, and the automobiles we drive. A quote by Thoreau reads: Simply to see a distant horizon through clean air is wealth enough for one afternoon. The final wayside on the right is titled, Rainshadow. Text reads: Farmland to the northeast must be irrigated. Less than 20 inches of rain falls there annually. Behind you only 40 miles to the west grows a dense rainforest, a dripping jungle of ferns and giant spruce in a Jack-in-the-beanstalk environment nurtured by 140 to 180 inches of rainfall per year. Mountains cast the shadow. Saturated Pacific winds rise steeply up the coastal slopes. As sudden altitude cools and condenses the air, most of the moisture is wrung out over the peaks by the time clouds reach this corner of the peninsula. Filling the left side of the panel is a drawing of a snow-capped mountain with clouds overhead, one cloud dropping lines of blue rain on the left side of the mountain. A white arrow in the rain points up slope. A smaller image to the right captioned, Rain forest, shows tree branches covered with draping moss.

data.title: Pillow Basalt view at Morse Creek Overlook
data.listingDescription: Across the road from the Morse Creek overlook, you may notice interesting rock formations, called "pillow basalt." From the U.S. Geological Survey: Basalt "pillows" form when lava cools quickly under water. The lack of bubbles in the lava suggests that the rock crystallized on the ocean floor under the pressure of deep water (preventing bubbles from forming in the lava).

images.altText: A road cut into a steep rocky mountainside.
images.caption: The pillow basalt alongside Hurricane Ridge Road. Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

data.bodyText: Across the road from the Morse Creek overlook, you may notice interesting rock formations, called "pillow basalt." From the U.S. Geological Survey: Basalt "pillows" form when lava cools quickly under water. The lack of bubbles in the lava suggests that the rock crystallized on the ocean floor under the pressure of deep water (preventing bubbles from forming in the lava).
data.audioDescription: Pillow Basalt Pullout/ Morse Creek Overlook. 25 seconds A three-foot-high stone wall rings the outer edge of the sidewalk located at this overlook. Beyond, overlapping mountains covered with green pine trees extend into the distance. Across the road from the overlook are rock formations on a brown, dirt hillside. The grey and brown rocks are ragged, cracked, and somewhat round in shape. Trees grow up hill from the rock formations.

data.title: Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home
data.listingDescription: Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home is where President Carter was raised from the age of four until he went to college at age seventeen. The Carter family owned this house until 1949, when Earl Carter sold it. The National Park Service received the home in 1994, and after a multiyear restoration to its 1937 appearance, opened the home to visitation in November of 2000.

images.altText: This white wooden framed house is where Jimmy Carter lived from age four to age seventeen.
images.title: Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home
images.caption: Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home

data.bodyText: Earl Carter moved his family to this house in 1928, when Jimmy was four years old. This three bedroom home served as the Carter home until 1949 when Earl Carter sold the house and the surrounding farm land. Jimmy Carter had left the home in 1941 to attend college. In 1994 the National Park Service purchased the house and seventeen acres to make up the park you see today. A multiyear restoration was started and the house and surrounding farm were returned to their 1937 appearance. In 2000 the house and surrounding farm was opened to the public as the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm.
data.audioDescription: The Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home is a wood framed house painted white. The front porch is screened in and serves as an extra room to the house. The house is surrounded by white sand and has a sidewalk in the front. A large Magnolia tree dominates the front view of the house on the right, while a Jessamine bush dominates the view on the left. In front of the Magnolia and next to the road is a silver mailbox on a wooden post.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: a circular passport cancellation stamp. A circle has the words Jimmy Carter National Historic Site- Boyhood Farm in the upper edge of the circle. The lower edge of the circle has the words Archery, Georgia. In the middle of the circle is a date of April 1, 2020.

data.title: US Navy Memorial
data.listingDescription: A memorial to the US Navy had always been part of Pierre L'Enfant's plan for Washingon, DC. However, it wasn't until 1987 that the US Navy Memorial was dedicated. The memorial design features a lone sailor in the midle of a granite sea surrounded by low, stone walls containing 26 bas-relief sculptures illustrating the history of the Navy and the sea services.

images.altText: A stone plaza in front of the neclassical National Archives building.
images.title: US Navy Memorial
images.caption: The stone plaza features fountains, artwork depicting scenes from naval history.

data.bodyText:
A memorial to the United States Navy had always been part of Pierre L'Enfant's plan for Washingon, DC. However, it wasn't until 1987 that the US Navy Memorial was dedicated. The memorial design features a lone sailor in the midle of a granite sea surrounded by low, stone walls containing 26 bas-relief sculptures illustrating the history of the Navy and the sea services.

Inscriptions

Entry steps, north side
ETERNAL FATHER STRONG TO SAVE
WHOSE ARM DOTH BIND THE RESTLESS WAVE
WHO BIDDST THE MIGHTY OCEAN DEEP
ITS OWN APPOINTED LIMITS KEEP
O, HEAR US WHEN WE CRY TO THEE,
FOR THOSE IN PERIL ON THE SEA
Navy Hymn, Eternal Father, 1860
Side benches
SIGHTED SUB. SANK SAME.
Aviation Machinists Mate 1/c Donald F. Mason, January 28, 1942
Aviation Pilot
THE SEA IS AN UNNATURAL ENVIRONMENT FOR MAN, AND IT TAKES SOMETHING EXTRA FOR MEN TO LIVE WITH IT
Paul H. Nitze October 27, 1965
UNDER WAY ON NUCLEAR POWER
Commander Eugene P. Wilkinson, Commanding USS Nautilus, January 17, 1955
WITHOUT A DECISIVE NAVAL FOCE
WE CAN DO NOTHING DEFINITIVE.
AND WITH IT EVERYTHING HONOURABLE AND GLORIOUS
General George Washington - Letter to Lafayette, November 15, 1781
WE HAVE MET THE ENEMY AND THEY ARE OURS
Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry, September 10, 1813
I WISH TO HAVE NO CONNECTION WITH ANY SHIP THAT DOES NOT SAIL FAST, FOR I INTEND TO GO IN HARM'S WAY
Captain John Paul Jones, November, 1778
Bas reliefs, left to right
UNITED STATES NAVY EXPLOSIVE ORDINANCE DISPOSAL
Bomb Disposal "Initial success...or total failure" Mine Disposal
Sculptor Leo C. Irrera
A diver swims underwater beneath mines set above him. Sailors float in a raft above.
NAVAL CONSTRUCTION BATTALIONS
"Seabees Can Do"
Sculptor Leo C. Irrera
A soldier with no shirt and rifle slung over his shoulder directs construction work of other soldiers below him.
THE NAVY FAMILY
"They Who Wait Also Serve"
Sculptor Robert Lamb
Women with babies and children wave to sailors standing along the edge of an aircraft carrier.
US NAVY SUPPLY CORPS "SERVICE TO THE FLEET"
USS ARLEIGH BURKE - USS SUPPLY
Sculptor Gilbert A. Franklin
A ship floats next to a larger ship. Ropes connect the two ships and a helicopter above carries a storage box hanging by a cable.
NAVY CHAPLAINS
"Eternal Father Strong to Save"
Sculptor Klara Sever
Sailors stand on the deck of a battleship, heads bowed, in front of a chaplain.
ADMIRAL DAVID FARRAGUT - MOBILE BAY - 1864
"Damn The Torpedoes - Full Speed Ahead"
Sculptor Robert Summers
Smoke billows from an ironclad ship in rough seas. A sail ship sits directly to the right with men on the deck.
NAVAL AVIATION - FIRST SHIPBOARD TAKEOFF
Eugene Ely - Hampton Roads - 1910
Sculptor Giancarlo Blagt
Two row boats with groups of about one dozen men each look above as a double-winged glider flies above them. The front corner of a large ship sits to the left.
INLAND NAVAL ENGAGEMENTS

Sculptor Serena Goldstein Litofsky
A soldier lies on the ground in a bunker with his machine gun and a soldier stands aiming his machine gun from a tripod. Two ships approach them along a river through jungle on both sides.
THE SILENT SERVICE "Clean Sweep"

Men stand on the deck of a submarine in the foreground as a submarine approaches. In the distance three submarines are lined together along a naval station.
NAVAL AIRSHIPS
"They Were Dependable"
Sculptor Miklos Simon
Two men sit in a cockpit. The sailor on the right looks back from his seat behind a circular steering wheel. A blimp floats above the sea in front of them.
NAVY MEDICINE
"Standing By To Assist"
Sculptor Antonio Tobias Mendez
A male and female soldier tend to a wounded man on the ground from a ship adorned with a medical cross. Four other sailors stand behind them, two on the right reach for a phone. A helicopter flies by smoke billowing from a mountain in front of them.
NAVAL RESERVISTS
"Twice A Citizen"

A sailor stands on a dock as a man walks behind him holding his military uniform. A second man approaches a walkway to a ship, also holding his military uniform.
NAVAL SPECIAL WARFARE
US Navy SEALs..."Failure is not an option"
Sculptor Leo C. Irrera
Two soldiers in the right foreground wait at the edge of a jungle as men in scuba gear emerge from the ocean. Four men in the distance parachute down toward the water as a helicopter turns away from them.
ENGINEERING DUTY OFFICERS

Sculptor Antonio Tobias Mendez
A man and woman in construction helmets look at a paper along with a person in military uniform on a dock. A ship and submarine docked behind them are being loaded with supplies by a rig.
WOMEN IN THE NAVY

Sculptor Serena Goldstein Litofsky
Two military women on either side of a man look at a document on board a ship. A military woman looks back at them from among other people at work on the ship.
THE GREAT WHITE FLEET - 1907

Sculptor Gilbert Franklin
A man in long coat and rimmed glasses tips his top hat to a steam-run battleship. A man in formal military uniform stands behind him from a balcony.
NAVY ASTRONAUTS AND RECOVERY MISSIONS

A tall sail ship floats in the background as two men in coats stand on the left shore with a dog to the right. Penguins gather on rocks in the sea behind them.
US MERCHANT MARINE - US NAVY ARMED GUARD
"We Deliver"
Sculptor Robert Lamb
Smoke billows from a ship far off in the sea and from a plane angling toward the water. A second plane flies beside it. Two solider is a gun turret aim a machine gun toward the planes and two soldiers in the foreground look on.
UNITED STATES NAVAL ACADEMY - ANNAPOLIS

Sculptor Miklos Simon
Men in military uniform walk along a walkway and two salute in the foreground as men march in line around a statue on both sides behind them. A woman and child approach from the left and a wide building sits in the background.
DESTROYER ESCORTS
"Trim But Deadly"
Sculptor Gilbert A. Franklin

OPENING JAPAN FOR COMMERCE
