data.title: Compton Peak Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Compton Gap Parking Area (mile 10.4) | A hike through the forest along the Appalachian Trail to a western view and a great look at columnar jointing, an exciting geologic feature.

images.altText: Columnar jointing, a large rock formation with stacked rock shaped like columns.
images.title: Compton Gap Trailhead

data.bodyText:
A hike through the forest along the Appalachian Trail to a western view and a great look at columnar jointing, an exciting geologic feature. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 2.4-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hours 45 minutes
Elevation Gain: 855 feet

Hike Description

  1.  From the Compton Gap Parking Area (mile 10.4), cross Skyline Drive and look for the concrete trail marker indicating the Appalachian Trail (A.T.).
  2. Take the A.T. south to the intersection and go right. This will lead you to the western viewpoint.
  3. Turn around, and return to the same intersection.
  4. Continue straight to the eastern viewpoint. From this viewpoint, you have the option of following the blue blazes below the cliff to see a prime example of columnar jointing, an amazing geological feature. It is well worth it, but be aware that this part of the hike is rough and rocky.
  5. Return back to the parking area by taking the A.T. north from the intersection.
data.audioDescription: The Compton Gap Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken of columnar jointing. The text reads, "Prismatic Features - Millions of years ago plates on the earth's surface in this area began pulling apart, and lava-at first it was black-colored basalt, but eventually it metamorphosed into the greenstone you see today- oozed up out of the earth and through the cracks between the plates. As the lava cooled, it shrank into intriguing six-sided shapes down through its depths, forming columns. Geologists call this columnar jointing. Take the Compton East hike (detailed below) to see an example of columnar jointing, one of the finest in the park." The photograph on the bottom left of the panel is of rocks and lichens in various shades of brown, rust, blue, green, and gray. The test reads, "Ancient Colors - Fort Windham Rocks and all the greenstone in this area are part of the Catoctin Formation, a series of related lava flows in Virginia, Maryland, and southern Pennsylvania. These rocks are being broken apart, little by little, by the power of ice and frost. Because the rocks at Fort Windham are covered with lichen and weathering rapidly, they feature some fascinating colors." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Compton Peak The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Compton Peak, West and East - 2.4-mile T-hike, moderate, 1.75 hours hiking time, 835-foot elevation gain. Cross Skyline Drive and begin at the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) post. Take the A.T. south to the trail post at the T-intersection. Go right at the post. Continue on the trail to the west viewpoint. Return to the intersection, and continue straight to the east viewpoint. The columnar jointing is underneath the east viewpoint; to see it, follow the blue blazes. This part of the trail is rough and rocky, but very short. When you reach the base of the cliff, look up to see the columnar jointing. Return the way you came, crossing Skyline Drive to reach the parking area." "Hike #2: Fort Windham Rocks - (This hike is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 0.8-mile round trip hike, easiest, Â½ hour hiking time, 130-foot elevation gain. Follow the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) north to its intersection with the Dickey Ridge Trail. Turn left. In about 300 yards, explore Fort Windham Rocks on the right. Return the way you came." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. - Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return.

data.title: Doyles River Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Doyles River Parking Area (mile 81.1) | This beautiful trek through Wilderness takes you along cool, clear mountain streams to two unique waterfalls.

images.altText: A color photograph of a tall waterfall in the forest.
images.title: Upper Doyles River Falls

data.bodyText:
This beautiful trek through Wilderness takes you along cool, clear mountain streams to two unique waterfalls. Be prepared for a stream crossing. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3.3-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,189 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Doyles River Parking Area (mile 81.1), take the blue-blazed Doyles River Trail.
  2. Cross the Appalachian Trail and pass the access trails to Doyles River Cabin and Browns Gap Road.
  3. Trail posts mark the locations of Upper and Lower Doyles River Falls.
  4. Retrace your steps to return to the parking area.
data.audioDescription: The Doyles River Falls Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken of an angler fishing in one of the mountain streams. The text reads, "At Doyles River you can play in the woods and in the water. Hike to a remote camping site, and fall asleep to the sounds of the nighttime forest. Look for squirrels and salamanders, and listen for owls, songbirds, and wood frogs. Capture the beauty of the forest on your camera: wildflowers, mushrooms, and the waterfalls and cascades of Doyles River and Jones Run. The deep pools are perfect for wading, and the tumbling water is great for fishing. Generations of people have escaped hectic lifestyles for the relaxation and rejuvenation that comes from the natural therapy of playing in Shenandoah National Park." "The tree shaded streams of the Park provide perfect habitat for native brook trout. Trout need cool, clean water that is well oxygenated from running over rocks and riffles. All of Shenandoah's streams are open to catch-and-release fishing, some are open for harvest. Check current Park regulations. A valid state fishing license is required." The photograph on the bottom left of the panel is two campers setting-up a blue and gray dome tent in a small clearing in the forest. The text reads, "Get away from the paved world by camping in Shenandoah's backcountry. Backcountry camping immerses you in nature, challenges your body, and refreshes your mind. If you have the right equipment and a free backcountry camping permit, you can camp almost anywhere in the Park. Talk to a Ranger to learn more about backcountry camping." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Doyles River Falls. The text reads, "Suggested Hike: Hike #1: Upper and Lower Doyles River Falls (This trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line.) "3.3-mile round trip, moderate, 2.25 hours hiking time, 1,189-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Follow Doyles River Trail. Pass the access trails for Doyles River Cabin and Browns Gap Road. Trail posts mark the location of Upper and Lower Doyles River Falls. Retrace your steps to return to the parking lot." "Hike #2: Doyles River Falls and Jones Run Falls - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 7.7-mile circuit, strenuous, 6.5 hours hiking time, 2,233-foot elevation gain, several stream crossings. Follow Doyles River Trail. Pass the access trails for Doyles River Cabin and Browns Gap Road. Trail posts mark the location of Upper and Lower Doyles River Falls. Another trail post marks the end of Doyles River Trail and the beginning of Jones Run Trail; follow Jones Run Trail. A trail post marks the location of Jones Run Falls. Continue uphill and turn right on the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) north. The A.T. crosses Skyline Drive twice before it brings you back to Doyles River parking." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

data.title: Frazier Discovery Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Loft Mountain Wayside (mile 79.5) | Pets are not allowed on this hike. This hike features several picturesque overlooks as it passes through woodlands of varying ages on Loft Mountain.

images.altText: A color panoramic photograph of a view over a rocky ledge into the valley below.
images.title: Frazier Discovery Trail

data.bodyText:
Pets are not allowed on this hike. This hike features several picturesque overlooks as it passes through woodlands of varying ages on Loft Mountain.

Distance: 1.2-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hour
Elevation Gain: 429 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the north end of the Loft Mountain Wayside Parking Area (mile 79.5), cross Skyline Drive and follow the blue-blazed Frazier Discovery Trail.
  2. Go right at the intersection and follow the steep uphill grade.
  3. Turn left where the trail joins the Appalachian Trail, staying on the blue-blazed trail.
  4. Turn left again at the next trail post to descend to your starting point.
data.audioDescription: The Frazier Discovery Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph of apples that are ready for harvest, by humans or the abundant wildlife that call the Park home. The text reads, "Gifts From the Land - Before the Park's establishment in the 1930s, Loft Mountain was home to farming people who settled here from Europe in the mid-1700s. They cleared the forest to provide pastureland for cattle and planted fruit trees-especially apples-for food. They brought plants with them from their home continent and planted them. When the National Park Service took possession of this land and these people had to move out, they left these plants behind. Many of them-especially apples-provide food for the deer, gray foxes, and bears that now call this land home." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a small bunch of blackberries, two of which are ripe for eating! The text reads, "A Forest Growing Up - Since the Park's establishment, the forest has been allowed to grow back. Most of what you see here are pioneer species - the kinds of plants and trees that spring up in the early stages of forest succession: coralberry, blackberry, Virginia creeper, hawthorn, and black locust. Eventually, as years pass, taller trees will start to shade out the shrubs and smaller plants that are typical of a young forest. This area will look very different as oak, hickory, and other mature-forest trees move in and take hold." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the Frazieer Discovery Trail hike. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Frazier Discovery Trail - 1.2-mile circuit, easiest, 1 hour hiking time, 429-foot elevation gain. Follow Frazier Discovery Trail and go right at the intersection. Go uphill to an intersection where Frazier Discovery Trail joins the Appalachian Trail and turn left. At the next trail post, go left onto Frazier Discovery Trail, and descend to the starting point." 'Hike #2: Loft Mountain Campground - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 3.6-mile lariat, moderate, 2½ hours hiking time, 752-foot elevation gain. Follow the path to your right. Continue uphill, pass the Loft Mountain campstore, and cross the road. Take the amphitheater access trail. Go left at the concrete trail post. Continue to the next trail post and go left onto the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) north. Follow the A.T. to the campstore access trail, where you will turn left and reconnect with the path, which leads back to the starting point." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets are not allowed on Frazier Discovery Trail. Where allowed, pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return.

data.title: Jones Run Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Jones Run Parking Area (mile 84.1) | This hike takes you over a mountain stream, through the forest, and beside a 42’ waterfall.

images.altText: A waterfall cascading over rock with slight hints of fall color in the trees above.
images.title: Jones Run Falls

data.bodyText:
This hike takes you over a mountain stream, through the forest, and beside a 42 foot waterfall. There is one stream crossing. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3.2-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,045 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Jones Run Parking Area (mile 84.1), cross the Appalachian Trail and follow the blue-blazed Jones Run Trail to Jones Run Falls
  2. Return by the same route.
data.audioDescription: The Jones Run Falls Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken along the shores of the Chesapeake Bay...a destination of the water that flows from this area of Shenandoah National Park. The text reads, "Keep It Clean - Jones Run is a source stream for the James River watershed, one of three major watersheds in Shenandoah National Park. Here is how the watershed works: Jones Run flows into the Doyles River, which flows into the Moormans River, which flows into the Rivanna River, which flows into the James River, which flows into the the Chesapeake Bay, which empties into the Atlantic Ocean. This means that what happens in Shenandoah's streams does not stay in Shenandoah's streams. Effects accumulate, good or bad, as the water travels to its final destination." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a handsome brook trout in its natural habitat. The text reads, "Full of Life - Pick up a rock and take a look. You'll see small creatures underneath it, like crayfish and caddisfly cases, evidence that Jones Run, like all of Shenandoah's streams, is teeming with activity. You might also see stoneflies and mayflies, indicators of good water quality and evidence that Shenandoah is sending clean water downstream. This tiny, aquatic life is also food for brook trout." "Brook trout thrive here in the mountains because they are cold water fish. Shenandoah's high elevation and shady forests keep the water cool. Brook trout are indicator species, so the fact that they're living in the Park means the streams are healthy and clean." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Jones Run Falls. The text reads, "Suggested Hike: Hike #1: Jones Run Falls - (This trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line.) 3.2-mile round trip, moderate, 2.25 hours hiking time, 1,045-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Follow Jones Run Trail to Jones Run Falls, and return by the same route." "Hike #2: Jones Run Falls and Doyles River Falls (The trail is marked in purple with a brown dashed line.) 6.5-mile circuit, moderately strenuous, 5 hours hiking time, 1,701-foot elevation gain, several stream crossings. Follow the Appalachian Trail north to Browns Gap parking. Without crossing Skyline Drive, walk several yards alongside the road until you reach Browns Gap Road on the right. Follow Browns Gap Road; turn right onto Doyles River Trail. Trail posts mark the location of Upper and Lower Doyles River Falls. Another trail post marks the end of Doyles River Trail and the beginning of Jones Run Trail. Follow Jones Run Trail. A trail post marks the location of Jones Run Falls. Continue uphill to return to the parking lot." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Leave what you find. Artifacts are protected by law. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

data.title: Riprap - Wildcat Ridge Trailhead
data.listingDescription: MILE 90 or 92.1 | This loop can be hiked from Riprap Parking or Wildcat Ridge Parking Areas. It takes you through pristine forest, over several stream crossings, and offers beautiful views of the hollows and valley to the west and north.

images.altText: A color photograph of a woman sitting on a rock atop a mountain looking to the side.
images.title: Riprap (Chimney Rocks)

data.bodyText:
You may choose start this hike at either the Riprap parking area or the Wildcat Ridge Parking Area. No matter which route you choose, this hike will take you through pristine forest and over several stream crossings, while offering beautiful views of the hollows and valleys to the west and north. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 9.8-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Very Strenuous (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 8 hours 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 2,365 feet

Hike Description - From Riprap Parking Area

  1. From the trailhead at the Riprap Parking Area (mile 90), follow the Appalachian Trail north.
  2. Turn left on Riprap Trail, continuing past Cavalry Rocks and Chimney Rocks.
  3. Turn left on Wildcat Ridge Trail.
  4. Take another left on the A.T. north, and return to your starting point. 


Hike Description - From Wildcat Ridge Parking Area

  1. From the trailhead at the Wildcat Ridge Parking Area (mile 92.1), take the Wildcat Ridge Trail past its intersection with the Appalachian Trail.
  2. Turn right onto Riprap Trail.
  3. Take another right on the A.T. south.
  4. Turn left on Wildcat Ridge Trail to return to your starting point.
data.audioDescription: The Wildcat Ridge Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a historic photograph of a CCC era fire watch tower. The black and white photo shows a more than 30 foot high wooden structure with an 8 sided platform. It is being constructed by a group of at least 5 men who are on the top of the platform and have accessed it via a wooden ladder. The text reads, "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. In the early 1930s, fire suppression was an important duty of the Civilian Conservation Corps crews stationed here. They built fire towers and manned them around the clock, scanning the horizon for any hint of smoke. Fire crews attacked whenever fire was detected, in an attempt to stop the destruction." "Meanwhile, local residents continued to annually burn their blackberry patches and meadows. They knew that fire regenerates many plants and keeps unwanted plants from choking out others." "Today, we know that both the CCC and the residents were doing the right thing. Unwanted fires caused by lightning or careless people can be destructive. But under the right conditions, fire can encourage healthy, diverse ecosystems. As you explore this area, you are likely to see evidence of past fires, both prescribed and wild." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike on the Wildcat Ridge Trail and Riprap Loop past Chimney Rock and Calvary Rocks. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hike: Hike: Riprap Loop. 9.8 mile circuit, very strenuous, 8.25 hours hiking time, 2,365-foot elevation gain, several stream crossings. You can hike this circuit clockwise or counter-clockwise. There's plenty to see and do either way: Straight on Wildcat Ridge Trail, right on Riprap Trail, right on Appalachian Trail (A.T.) south, and left back to the parking lot; or right on A.T. north, left on Riprap Trail; left on Wildcat Ridge Trail, and back to the parking lot." "The section between the Riprap - Wildcat Ridge intersection and Chimney Rock is especially beautiful: lush forest, showy rhododendrons in season (late May), and a wonderful series of streams with cascades and an "ole swimming hole" that's legendary." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."

quickFacts.value: Riprap Parking Area (Mile 90) or Wildcat Ridge Parking Area (mile 92.1)
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Big Meadows Picnic Grounds
data.listingDescription: Located next to the Big Meadows Campground, Big Meadows Picnic Grounds provides an open space to relax, complete with picnic tables and grills.

images.altText: An open grassy area with trees in the distance.
images.title: Big Meadows Picnic Ground

data.bodyText:
Located next to the Big Meadows Campground, Big Meadows Picnic Grounds provides an open space to relax, complete with picnic tables and grills. Just be sure to store your food properly and dispose of any trash so that it'll be just as beautiful on your next picnic! The Big Meadows amphitheater is also located at the far end of the picnic ground.

Although some picnic grounds remain open year-round, Big Meadows picnic grounds closes during the winter. Please check our operating hours for more information.
data.audioDescription: The road at Big Meadows Picnic Ground is a one way loop. Inside the loop is a field with scattered picnic tables and grills. There is a restroom building in the center.

data.title: Dark Hollow Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Dark Hollow Falls Parking Area (mile 50.7) | Pets are not allowed on this hike. This hike follows a stream to a beautiful waterfall, and is one of the Park’s most traveled trails. The trail is short, but very steep and rocky and the return hike is challenging!

images.altText: A waterfall cascades under trees with the yellow leaves of fall.
images.title: Dark Hollow Falls

data.bodyText:
Pets are not allowed on this hike. The steep descent following a stream to this beautiful waterfall is one of the Park’s most traveled trails. This trail is short, but very steep and rocky. The return climb is challenging! Know your limits and take your time, especially when the trail is wet and slippery.

Distance: 1.4-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hour 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 440 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Dark Hollow Falls Parking Area (mile 50.7), descend 0.75-mile down to the falls.
  2. Return by the same route, up to the parking area.
data.audioDescription: The Dark Hollow Falls Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph of the water cascading over the rocks of Dark Hollow. The text reads, "Water on the Rocks - The splashing stream that you follow to Dark Hollow Falls is a life saver. Starting from springs less than a mile away, the water nourishes plants, animals and humans. Park biologists keep an eye on changes in streams such as this one, to reduce negative impacts from humans and weather. Temperature changes of just a few degrees or high acid levels can make streams unlivable for many species. Once the water tumbles through Dark Hollow and leaves the Park, it joins other streams and rivers and passes through farmland, housing developments, towns, and industrial areas along its journey to Chesapeake Bay. Will it still be able to sustain life when it gets there?" There are four smaller pictures on the bottom left of the panel: a crayfish, purple-flowering raspberry, an ovenbird, and jewelweed. The text reads, "Who lives here? Take time to see and hear what's around you as you hike. In the stream, look for crayfish, brook trout, salamanders, and frogs. Listen for redstarts and ovenbirds. Bursts of color herald the seasons: trillium in spring, purple-flowering raspberry in summer, and jewelweed from summer into fall." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Dark Hollow Falls. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hike: Hike: Dark Hollow Falls - 1.4-mile, round trip, moderate, 1 hours hiking time, 440-foot elevation gain. Follow the trail 0.75-mile to the base of the falls and return by the same route. If you plan to continue hiking beyond the falls, obtain a map from the visitor center for trail information. This trail is short, but very steep and rocky. The return climb is challenging! Sturdy shoes with gripping soles such as hiking boots and sneakers are best suited for the rocky terrain found on this hike. Stay on the trail and do not venture out onto the rocks near the waterfall. These rocks are very slippery and dangerous. The pathway that crosses Skyline Drive joins the Story of the Forest Trail which leads to Byrd Visitor Center (0.4-mile) and to Big Meadows Campground (0.66-mile). Pets are not allowed on this trail." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at Entrance Stations, Visitor Centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Pets are not allowed on Dark Hollow Falls Trail. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return.

data.title: El Tovar Monument
data.listingDescription: The first modern hotel constructed in the Village, El Tovar Hotel eventually became the eventual heart of Grand Canyon National Park, and a National Historical Landmark. Constructed to the highest standards of the time, El Tovar Hotel helped lure visitors to a remote and rough canyon region.

images.altText: A waist-high stone pedestal with a bronze plaque on the top commemorates the El Tovar Hotel.
images.title: El Tovar Monument
images.caption: El Tovar Hotel was designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1987.

data.bodyText:
In the median of the driveway just outside the entrance of El Tovar Hotel, a plaque commemorates the site as a National Historic Landmark.

The first modern hotel constructed in the Village, El Tovar Hotel became the eventual heart of Grand Canyon National Park, and a National Historical Landmark.

Constructed to the highest standards of the time, El Tovar Hotel helped lure visitors to a remote and rough canyon region to enjoy unparalleled views while offering a place of respite, comfort, and luxury following a hot, dusty day of travel or exploration.

The National Historic Landmarks Program, established in 1935, is administered by the National Park Service on behalf of the Secretary of the Interior. The agency works with preservation officials, private property owners, and other partners interested in nominating properties for National Historic Landmark designation. Completed nominations are reviewed by the National Park System Advisory Board, which makes recommendations for designation to the Secretary of the Interior.
data.audioDescription: In front of the east entrance to the El Tovar Hotel, near the center of a 50-foot (15 m) wide circle ringed by the loop road, stands a three-foot (1 m) tall rectangular limestone-block pedestal with a roughly 16-inch (40 cm) square metal plaque mounted at a slight angle on the top. Move carefully across the road using the crosswalk in front of the hotel veranda. Text on the plaque reads: "El Tovar has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America, 1987, National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior."

data.title: Hopi House and El Tovar Waysides
data.listingDescription: As two of the earliest permanent structures catering to the needs of modern visitors in the Grand Canyon Village the El Tovar and the Hopi draw inspiration from two very different locations and cultures yet both were designed to attract people to the wonders and stories of this one-of-a-kind place.

images.altText: A pair of shaded, angled waysides discuss two of the oldest buildings in Grand Canyon Village.
images.title: Hopi House and El Tovar Waysides
images.caption: Built in 1905, these two buildings mark the beginning of what would become Grand Canyon Village.

data.bodyText: Two of the earliest permanent structures catering to the needs of modern visitors in the Grand Canyon Village, the El Tovar Hotel and Hopi House draw inspiration from very different cultures and architectural styles, yet both were designed to attract people to the wonders and stories of this one-of-a-kind place.
data.audioDescription: About 50 feet (15 m) west of Hopi House, in a shady area with a couple trees just before you reach the loop road, stand a couple three-foot (1 m) tall metal wayside panels with angled reading rails. On the left panel, an old black-and-white photograph shows a couple men and women standing in front of a nearly completed structure. Text at the top left reads: "Hopi House. Hopi House opened to the public in 1905. In an era when most architects were men, it was Mary Elizabeth Jane Colter's first building. The 36-year-old Colter enlisted the help of local Hopi craftsmen to build Hopi House, using locally quarried stone and wood harvested from the nearby forest. Hopi House was not just a curio store, it was also a place from where American Indian artisans lived and worked. Under the watchful eyes of visitors, these artisans would create beautiful jewelry, pottery, blankets, and other items that would then be sold at Hopi House, forging a personal connection to the items visitors purchased there." A quote at the top from Virginia Grattan's 1992 book, "Mary Colter: Builder Upon the Red Earth," reads: "For Mary Colter, Hopi House was an opportunity to re-create the distinctive dwelling of an ancient culture and to acquaint the public with the richness and beauty of Native American art." The first of two inset black-and-white photographs at the bottom right shows a Hopi village filled with similar stone buildings and terraces with the caption: "Colter modeled Hopi House after centuries-old villages on the Hopi Reservation." At the bottom right, a second photograph shows a half-dozen men and women with their wares seated on an elaborate rug in front of Hopi House with the caption: "Hopi artisans and their families, in exchange for their artwork and demonstrations, received wages and lodging at Hopi House. Today, various tribes demonstrate traditional dance and art, but they are no longer housed here." On the right panel, an old black-and-white photograph shows about 15 well-dressed visitors standing on the El Tovar veranda with a black convertible motorcar parked out front. Text at the top left reads: "El Tovar Hotel. The El Tovar Hotel was a game changer. Prior to its construction most Grand Canyon visitors slept in tent accommodations on the South Rim. Opening to great fanfare on January 14, 1905, the hotel catered to a wealthy clientele. Imagine guests' delight upon finding a music room, a solarium, a billiard hall, an underground grotto (where men enjoyed a friendly game of cards), a barbershop, two roof gardens, an art room, and gift shop. For $4.50 and upwards per night, guests were treated to finely decorated rooms with both hot and cold running water." Text to the right of the photograph reads: "Keeping with the Santa Fe Railway's affinity for naming their hotels after Spanish explorers, "El Tovar" honored Don Pedro de Tovar, who visited the Hopi mesas to the east in 1540." A quote from the Coconino Sun from May 24, 1902 at the top right reads: "The Santa Fe is going to build the most expensive hotel...at the Grand Canyon...the idea of the architect is to bring the building into harmony with the wonderful scenery of the canyon rather than to put a blot upon its beauty by the erection of a conventional structure." A second black-and-white photograph inset at the bottom right shows the interior of one of the rooms with two wooden sleigh beds, a couple rocking chairs, a large dresser topped with a mirror, and a smaller vanity. A caption reads: "Early 20th century visitors enjoyed the comforts and luxuries of the El Tovar."

data.title: Loft Mountain Wayside
data.listingDescription: The Loft Mountain Wayside is a great stop for a quick meal and souvenirs. Loft Mountain Wayside usually closes around the beginning of November and reopens in April. Call 877-847-1919 for exact dates. There is an orientation shelter in front of the wayside, along with a backcountry registration board, a bike repair station, and picnic tables. https://www.goshenandoah.com/dining/food-groceries

images.altText: A rustic dark brown wood-sided building with dark green trim.
images.title: Loft Mountain Wayside
images.caption: Food and souvenirs make this a great stop.

data.bodyText: The Loft Mountain Wayside is a great stop for a quick meal and souvenirs. Loft Mountain Wayside usually closes around the beginning of November and reopens in April. Call 877-847-1919 for exact dates. There is an orientation shelter in front of the wayside, along with a backcountry registration board, a bike repair station, and picnic tables. https://www.goshenandoah.com/dining/food-groceries
data.audioDescription: A rustic dark brown wood-sided building with dark green trim. A center double door divides the two sides. A sidewalk leads to the door. The interpretive sign is a 36 by 24 inch color graphic panel on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The title text reads, "Smarter Than Your Average Bear..." The body text reads, "... is pretty smart. Black bears are wily omnivores-quick learners who can easily destroy any tent or container to get at your food! Black bears thrive in Shenandoah National Park because the foods they need to eat-acorns, berries, grubs, honey-are plentiful. Human food is bad news for bears, and all Park wildlife. Bears that get human food lose their fear of humans. They are at a much greater risk for being illegally hunted and hit by vehicles. A "good bear gone bad" is dangerous to people and may have to be trapped and relocated or even killed by Park staff. Bears have an astounding sense of smell. They also have claws and strong teeth, which means they can make quick work of even a metal cooler. When you're picnicking in bear country, store your food properly and don't leave it unattended, even for a few moments. Remember to put all food and packaging inside your vehicle and dispose of garbage in bear-proof trashcans." The text is on top of a bright green background. To the left of the text is an image of a bear surrounded by green ferns, looking straight forward at the viewer. The caption for the image reads, "Black bear." A black bar on the top of the graphic reads "Shenandoah National Park" on the left and on the right is the National Park Service Arrowhead symbol with the text "National Park Service/U.S. Department of the Interior" The orientation shelter is a small roof supported by six brown beams. The beams are frames for six upright 36 inch by 54 inch posters in glass enclosures. Panel 1: Bulletin Board Bulletin boards contain seasonal information. Panel 2: Shenandoah Map This graphic is divided into two columns, the left has text and images and the right has a map. On the right column, title text reads, "Welcome to Shenandoah National Park." Below the title is a color photograph of a man standing atop a rock outcrop and looking to the mountains in the distance on a sunny day. Layered on the image is the quote " ...for the recreation and the re-creation they shall find here." -President Franklin Roosevelt, Shenandoah's Dedication." Text below the image reads, "Shenandoah National Park was established in 1935 to bring the western national park experience to the urban east. Here, within a few hours' drive of millions, you will find "recreation and re-creation." Experience the wonder of nature, the power of shared heritage, and the inspiration that is the future of our national parks." Below there is the subheading "Shenandoah Highlights," and the text "- Skyline Drive - 105 miles of beauty. Please observe the 35 mph speed limit to see it all safely. - 75 Overlooks - Spectacular views of the Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. - 500 Miles of Trails - Beautiful waterfalls, quiet forests, and mountain summits are just a hike away. - Visitor Centers - Films, exhibits, and Ranger-led walks and talks tell Shenandoah's stories." The map to the right shows the boundaries of, driving route through, and highlights in Shenandoah National Park. The map area is 30 miles wide by 150 miles long. Shenandoah National Park is shaded green. Highlights include entrance stations, visitor centers, campgrounds, lodging, restrooms, food services, and trailheads. At the bottom of the map is the park emergency number: (800) 732-0911. At the top and bottom of the graphic are black bars. The black bar at the top has the text, "Shenandoah National Park," to the left, and "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior," on the right with the National Park Service arrowhead logo to the far right. The lower black bar has the Leave No Trace logo on the left with the text "Leave No Trace Principe #6, Respect Wildlife," and on the right the text "www.nps.gov/shen." Panel 3: Spring/Summer Plants and Animals. The graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting."

data.title: Story of the Forest Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Byrd Visitor Center (mile 51) | Pets are not allowed on this hike. An easier stroll through the woods that passes next to the Big Meadows Air Quality Station, an important place for scientists and researchers to learn about air quality in Shenandoah.

images.altText: A wooden sign that reads, “Story of the Forest” and has an arrow pointing to the right.
images.title: Story of the Forest Trail

data.bodyText:
Pets are not allowed on this hike. An easier stroll through the woods that passes next to the Big Meadows Air Quality Station, an important place for scientists and researchers to learn about air quality in Shenandoah.

Distance: 1.8-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 1 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 290 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From Byrd Visitor Center (mile 51), follow the sidewalk to the trailhead and take the trail right. 
  2. After crossing the bridge, turn left and follow the trail to its intersection with a paved walkway near the campground office.
  3. Turn left and follow the walkway back to your starting point.
data.audioDescription: A brown wooden sign that reads "Story of the Forest Trail" with an arrow pointing right, leading to a path through the forest. Along the trail there is an interpretive sign near the location of an air quality monitoring station. The Air quality station is located through the woods in a locked enclosure. Within the enclosure are many scientific instruments for collecting rain and air samples. The sign is a 24 by 36 inch color graphic on a dark metal frame angled towards the viewer. The graphic has the title "Getting to know the air you breathe." Above the title is the quote, "Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It's not." -The Lorax, Dr. Seuss. Below the title is the text, "Every living thing is affected by what's in the air. To protect and improve air quality, it's vital to know what's in the air, how it got there, and how it affects plants, animals, and humans. The Big Meadows air quality station does exactly that. This equipment collects data on weather, visibility, ozone levels, and pollutants in the air. Scientists across the nation use the data to advise protection agencies and lawmakers about regulations that will help reduce pollution and protect the air we breathe. This monitoring station has been providing data for 30 years, giving scientists some of the most valuable information available about trends in air quality over time. The data shows that when strong regulations are in place, the quality of air improves. Cleaner air means cleaner water, healthier lives for plants, animals, and humans, and more beautiful views from the peaks and overlooks of Shenandoah. Learn more about air quality monitoring and what you can do at Byrd Visitor Center, or visit out website: www.nps.gov/shen." To the right of the text is a large color photograph with three color photographs below it. The large image shows a view over mountains and out to a valley in three different days with decreasing visibility and haze over the valley. The text below this image reads, "Spectacular views in Shenandoah's overlooks and mountains draw visitors from around the world. Protecting the views is part of the responsibility of being a national park. Scientists estimate that without pollution you could see 115 miles. But these days, increased haze limits your view to just 23 miles on average. Clear days are a rare treat, with moderate days being the norm. A string of hot, humid days can produce poor visibility that obscures even the closest range. Below, the first image is a photograph of a single green leaf with small spots on it. A caption reads, "Among national parks, Shenandoah experiences some of the highest ground-level ozone. One of the first signs of damage appears as brown spots on milkweed leaves." The second image is a photograph of a waterfall cascading over rocks and into the stream below with the caption, "Acid rain pollutes our streams and endangers fragile aquatic life. What appear to be clear mountain streams can be lethal to the acid-sensitive fish that live here." The third image is a close up photograph of one of the scientific instruments at the air quality station. The caption reads, "Each piece of equipment collects information that helps scientists understand and fight for what's needed to protect Shenandoah's vital resources. You can help!" At the bottom of the poster is the note, "Funded in part by the Shenandoah National Park Trust."

data.title: Sugarloaf Loop Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Piney River Parking Area (mile 22) | Follow the trail to a viewpoint. In the early summer, the showy white flowers of mountain laurel bloom in abundance here.

images.altText: A color photograph with the sun illuminating a snowy trail with a concrete trailpost on the left.
images.title: Piney River Trailhead in Winter

data.bodyText:
Sugarloaf Loop leads to a scenic viewpoint. In the early summer, the showy white flowers of mountain laurel bloom in abundance here. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 5.0-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 7 hours
Elevation Gain: 1,120 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Piney River Parking Area (mile 22), take the Piney Branch Upper Trail to its intersection with the Pole Bridge Link Trail.
  2. Go left on the Pole Bridge Link Trail.
  3. Turn left onto Sugarloaf Trail. This will bring you out near Skyline Drive, above Hogback Overlook.
  4. Turn left to take the Appalachian Trail (white-blazed) back to your starting point.
data.audioDescription: The Piney River Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54-inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a black and white photograph of one of the original Civilian Conservation Corps buildings. The foreground is a 1930s era pick-up truck. The text reads, "Camp Red Bird - The Piney River area was home to NP-12, "Camp Red Bird," of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), a work-relief program during the Great Depression. From 1935 to 1942, the camp housed hundreds of young men who learned skills, earned much-needed money, and helped build Shenandoah National Park. The building to your right is one of the few remaining original CCC buildings." The photograph on the bottom left is a black and white historic picture of Range View Cabin with a man sitting on a stump just beyond the overhang of the shelter. The text reads, "Range View Cabin - Just down the trail is Range View Cabin, one of six cabins operated by the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC). With the exception of the stonework, PATC volunteers built the cabin in 1932. The club hired local stonemason, Charlie Sisk, whose skills were also frequently used at Skyland." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20-inch topographic map of the hikes at Piney River. The trail to Range View Cabin is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Range View Cabin - 1.8-mile round trip, easiest, 1-¼ hours hiking time, 150-foot elevation gain. Follow the Piney Branch Trail to your left. At the junction with the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) turn right to head south. Turn left onto the Range View Service Road and follow this road to the cabin. Retrace your steps to return to the parking lot." "Hike #2 - Sugarloaf Loop - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 4.9-mile circuit, moderate, 3-½ hours hiking time, 956-foot elevation gain. Follow the Piney Branch Trail to your left. At the junction with the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) stay left to follow the Piney Branch Trail for another 1.5 miles. Turn left onto the Pole Bridge Link Trail and follow this trail for .4 miles to the Sugarloaf Trail. Turn left onto the Sugarloaf Trail and continue for 1.4 miles to the intersection with the A.T. Make a left to head south on the A.T. for 1.2 miles to the intersection with the Piney River Branch Trail. Turn right to return to this parking area." "Exploring Further. This trailhead also leads to a network of many trails and former road traces. If you are not familiar with the area, you should get a map. See the opposite side of this kiosk for a detailed map of the Mathews Arm and Overall Run Falls area." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at Entrance Stations, Visitor Centers, and www.nps.gov/shen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Pets must be on a leash no longer than six feet. When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return."

data.title: Turk Mountain Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Turk Mountain Parking Area (Mile 94.1) | A hike to the 2,981’ summit of Turk Mountain that provides a wonderful view to the west.

images.altText: A summer view of green bushes in the foreground and a large mountain in the right background.
images.title: Summer View from Turk Mountain Overlook

data.bodyText:
A hike to the 2,981 foot summit of Turk Mountain that provides a wonderful view to the west. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 2.2-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Easiest (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 690 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the Turk Mountain Parking Area (mile 94.1), cross Skyline Drive and take the Appalachian Trail south to the trailpost.
  2. Go right onto the Turk Mountain Trail and follow it to the summit for a wonderful view to the west.
  3. Retrace your steps to return to your starting point.
data.audioDescription: This overlook faces northwest. Straight ahead is the peak of Turk Mountain. Descending to the left from Turk Mountain is Sawmill Ridge. Further left is the smaller and closer Scott Mountain. From Turk Mountain to the right the mountain descends and the Shenandoah Valley appears in the distance.

data.title: Whiteoak Canyon Falls Upper Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Whiteoak Canyon Parking Area (mile 42.6) | This challenging hike to cascades and waterfalls has been popular since the early days of Skyland Resort. This particular hike goes to the upper falls before returning.

images.altText: Looking downward over a rocky ledge at a tall waterfall cascading down a canyon in the fall.
images.title: Upper Whiteoak Falls

data.bodyText:
This challenging hike to cascades and waterfalls has been popular since the early days of Skyland Resort. This particular hike goes to the upper falls before returning. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 4.6-mile round trip hike
Difficulty: Moderate (hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 3 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 1,040 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead at the Whiteoak Canyon Parking Area (mile 42.6), take the Whiteoak Canyon Trail.
  2. Pass the junctions for the Old Rag Fire Road and the Limberlost Trail.
  3. About 2.3 miles from the start you will come to a rocky ledge with a view of the upper falls.
  4. Retrace your steps to return to the parking lot.
data.audioDescription: The Whiteoak Canyon Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a black and white historic photograph of a group of more than 30 early Skyland Resort visitors taken near the head of the falls. The text reads, "A Popular Playground - The waterfalls of Whiteoak Canyon may well be the reason that Shenandoah National Park even exists. Long before this area was a national park, it was a popular playground for the early visitors to Skyland Lodge. There was even a lodge in the area near the first falls complete with a bridge, a dam, a swimming pool, and bath houses! Fortunately, White Oak Canyon has returned at least partially to its natural state, but remnants of the lodge can still be seen in the stone staircase between the first and second waterfalls." The picture on the bottom left of the panel shows a hiker on a large boulder overlooking the cascading stream. The text reads, "A Walk on the Wild Side - White Oak Canyon is home to impressive waterfalls and cascades that range in height from 35 to 86 feet. As you make your way toward the falls, be sure to take in the rugged and wild scene unfolding before you. The canyon's steep gorge and sheer rock walls soar upward from the water while the falls start as a trickle and build into a rush of water that tumbles into the pools below." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to Whiteoak Canyon. The trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Upper White Oak Falls - 4.6-mile round trip, moderate, 3Â½ hour hiking time, 1,040 foot elevation gain. Follow the White Oak Canyon Trail and stay on this trail as you pass the junctions for the Old Rag Fire Road and the Limberlost Trail. About 2.3 miles from the start you will come to a rocky ledge that offers an excellent view of the upper falls. Retrace your steps to return to the parking lot. Remember that the return trip will be very steep." "Hike #2: White Oak Canyon - (This trail is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 7.3-mile round trip, strenuous, 6 hours hiking time, 2,150 foot elevation gain. Please consider your physical condition and available time before embarking on this hike. Follow the White Oak Canyon Trail past the upper falls for another 1.3 miles down the canyon to the lower falls. Return via the same route. The trail on this section is narrow, rocky, and steep." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Do not attempt to cross streams during icy conditions or flooding. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water-at least a quart per hour. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking. Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitor centers, and www.nps.gov/shen - When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return." A Hiking Difficulty Scale reads: "Easiest - A hike that is generally suitable for anyone who enjoys walking. Mostly level or with a slight incline. Generally less than 3 miles. Moderate - A moderate hike generally suitable for novice hikers seeking a bit of a challenge. The terrain will involve a moderate incline and may have some steeper sections. Generally 3 to 5 miles. Moderately Strenuous - Generally challenging for an unconditioned person. The terrain will involve a steady and often steep incline. Generally 5 to 8 miles. Strenuous - Will challenge most hikers. The hike will generally be longer and steeper, but may be deemed strenuous because of the elevation gain. Generally 7 to 10 miles. Very Strenuous. Only well-conditioned and well-prepared hikers should attempt. Generally long and steep, and may include rock scrambling, stream crossings, and other challenging terrain. Generally 8 miles and over."

data.title: C&O Canal Lock 33

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.
data.audioDescription: (103 words) Lock 33 is located on the towpath in Knoxville, Maryland. From the Harpers Ferry access point turn left, or Northwest, onto the towpath. After 350 feet, the lock will appear on the right. The lock is about five feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock walls are made of stone blocks. The two walls make a chamber that is about twelve feet deep. The upstream and downstream entrance gates are missing. Behind the lock, beyond an additional stone wall and a road, are the remains of lockhouse 33. On the opposite side of the towpath is the Potomac River.

data.title: Skyland Lodging
data.listingDescription: If you're staying at Skyland, the Skyland Registration Office will be your first stop to check in. Lodging accommodations range from premium rooms to detached small cabins, preferred and traditional rooms, suites, and pet friendly rooms - located in 28 separate buildings along the ridge and in the wooded areas on over 27 acres of Shenandoah National Park.

images.altText: A hotel room with two beds and a view through the window of blue mountains.
images.title: Skyland Lodge Preferred Room

data.bodyText:
If you're staying at Skyland, the Skyland Registration Office will be your first stop to check in. Lodging accommodations range from premium rooms to detached small cabins, preferred and traditional rooms, suites, and pet friendly rooms - located in 28 separate buildings along the ridge and in the wooded areas on over 27 acres of Shenandoah National Park.

Skyland typically opens in the spring and closes in late fall and is operated by the Park concessioner, Delaware North. More information about rates, reservations, and operating hours can be found on their website.

Through the panes is the registration area for Skyland visitors. There is a sidewalk leading up to the office. Just outside the registration building there is an orientation kiosk: The orientation shelter is a small roof supported by six brown beams. The beams are frames for six upright 36 inch by 54 inch posters in glass enclosures. Panel 1. Bulletin Board Bulletin boards contain seasonal information. Panel 2. Park Map. This graphic is divided into two columns, the left has text and images and the right has a map. On the right column, title text reads, "Welcome to Shenandoah National Park." Below the title is a color photograph of a man standing atop a rock outcrop and looking to the mountains in the distance on a sunny day. Layered on the image is the quote ‘...for the recreation and the re-creation they shall find here." -President Franklin Roosevelt, Shenandoah's Dedication." Text below the image reads, "Shenandoah National Park was established in 1935 to bring the western national park experience to the urban east. Here, within a few hours' drive of millions, you will find "recreation and re-creation." Experience the wonder of nature, the power of shared heritage, and the inspiration that is the future of our national parks." Below there is the subheading "Shenandoah Highlights," and the text "- Skyline Drive - 105 miles of beauty. Please observe the 35 mph speed limit to see it all safely. - 75 Overlooks - Spectacular views of the Shenandoah Valley and Virginia Piedmont. - 500 Miles of Trails - Beautiful waterfalls, quiet forests, and mountain summits are just a hike away. - Visitor Centers - Films, exhibits, and Ranger-led walks and talks tell Shenandoah's stories." The map to the right shows the boundaries of, driving route through, and highlights in Shenandoah National Park. The map area is 30 miles wide by 150 miles long. Shenandoah National Park is shaded green. Highlights include entrance stations, visitor centers, campgrounds, lodging, restrooms, food services, and trailheads. At the bottom of the map is the park emergency number: (800) 732-0911. At the top and bottom of the graphic are black bars. The black bar at the top has the text, "Shenandoah National Park," to the left, and "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior," on the right with the National Park Service arrowhead logo to the far right. The lower black bar has the Leave No Trace logo on the left with the text "Leave No Trace Principe #6, Respect Wildlife," and on the right the text "www.nps.gov/shen." Panel 3. Spring/Summer. The graphic is split into two horizontal sections with text and graphics in rectangles. The top section has the title, "Spring" with the subtitle "Renewal." The rectangle is split vertically. The left side contains three color photographs with text descriptions. The first image is white flowers with four petals labeled "Flowering Dogwood," and the accompanying text, "Dogwood blossoms are well-known messengers of spring, but this understory tree has other jobs, too - like providing food and shelter." The second image shows a mother deer and two fawns walking in high grasses labeled "White-tailed Deer" with the accompanying text "White-tailed deer hide their fawns under the dogwood's low-hanging branches and feed on its tender shoots, buds, and later, berries." The third image shows a dark blue bird with black tail feathers labeled "Indigo Bunting," and the accompanying text "Indigo buntings often build their nests in dogwood trees and line them with deer hair. Birds love the berries' high fat content, a great trade-off for the dogwood, since its seeds are spread by those who eat them, ensuring the dogwood's renewal." The right side of the top panel contains the text, "From the moment the first plant pushes up through the forest floor beginning its annual growth cycle, spring is renewal. Hungry black bears come out of their dens with winter-born cubs. Migratory birds return, butterflies emerge, and wildflowers herald the season. Every life, new and old, depends on another." There are nine color photographs under this text arranged in a 3 by 3 square. From the top left they are: a bush with clumps of white flowers labeled "Mountain Laurel," a butterfly with white and yellow markings and blue tips on the wings labeled "Eastern Tiger Swallowtail," round mounds of fungus growing out of the forest floor labeled "Morel Mushrooms" a small curled up salamander labeled "Red-backed Salamander," a bird with yellow, black, and white markings labeled "Chestnut-sided Warbler," a single white flower with three petals and large green leaves labeled "Large-flowered Trillium," a light brown toad on the ground labeled "Spring Pepper," a set of three yellow and red bell shaped flowers labeled "Wild Columbine," and a bird with a white chest and tan head and wings.

data.title: Big Meadows
data.listingDescription: Skyline Drive (mile 51) | Perched on top of a mountain, this high-elevation meadow can come as a bit of a surprise after the miles of lush, green forests that make up most of Shenandoah National Park. A must-see for every visitor, stop by Big Meadows to explore the trails, grab a bite to eat, or talk to a Ranger at Byrd Visitor Center.

images.altText: A large, grassy meadow with a line of dark trees in the background.
images.title: Big Meadows

data.bodyText:
Perched on top of a mountain, this high-elevation meadow can come as a bit of a surprise after the miles of lush, green forests that make up most of Shenandoah National Park.

While the exact reasons for its existence remain unclear, Big Meadows provides essential habitat for many plants and animals, as well as opportunities for visitors to view wildlife, stargaze, or to simply wander the many paths that weave throughout this unique ecosystem. Located near the center of the Park, Big Meadows also provides a convenient place to base your Shenandoah adventure. There are many services just a short walk or drive away:

Byrd Visitor Center 

Big Meadows Wayside and Lodge 

Big Meadows Campground 

Big Meadows Picnic Ground

Hiking trails
data.passportStampLocationDescription: Located at the information desk in Byrd Visitor Center.

quickFacts.value: Wildlife, wildflowers, unique habitat, history, views
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Catoctin Creek Aqueduct

images.altText: The three arch aqueduct spans a creek.
images.title: Catoctin Creek Aqueduct
images.caption: Catoctin Creek Aqueduct

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText:
The C&O Canal aqueducts are “water bridges” that carried canal boats over the creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac River. Built in 1832, the Catoctin Aqueduct is the fourth of eleven such “works of art” on the canal.

The Catoctin Creek Aqueduct was known as the "Crooked Aqueduct" because canal boats had to make a sharp turn to cross it. From its original creation, the Catoctin Creek Aqueduct's structural integrity was questionable. The elliptical arch in the center was not as structurally sound as the semicircle arches on either side. The aqueduct began sagging in the early 1900s. It leaked and was prone to flooding. In 1973, two years after Congress established the C&O Canal National Historical Park, it collapsed, leaving only a small piece standing.

The Park Service gathered up the aqueduct’s stones and buried them with the hopes that someday the aqueduct would be restored. Nearly 35 years later, a restoration project gained enough funding to rebuild. The four hundred and fifty-nine stones where uncovered and the engineering crew began to fit the blocks together like a giant 3-demensional puzzle. Each stone was measured, and the crew used those measurements to create foam stones. Historic photos were then used to identify where individual stones were positioned. Missing stones or those in poor condition were replaced. In a little over a year, construction was complete. Today, new viewing areas and waysides allow visitors to learn about the structure and the efforts to rebuild it.
data.audioDescription: (268 words) Catoctin Aqueduct is located along the towpath in Jefferson, Maryland. It is 92 feet long with a three-arch construction. This aqueduct has an elliptical center arch with two semicircle arches on either side of the center arch. The top of the aqueduct has a water way for the canal boats and a towpath for the mules. The waterway of the aqueduct is about 15 feet wide and its bottom is about six feet lower than the towpath. To get to the aqueduct start from the Lock 29 (Lander) parking lot. Head Northwest from the parking lot to reach the road you drove in on. On the road, head Southwest, about 80 feet, or until you reach the wooden bridge. The pedestrian bridge crosses the middle of lock 29 and has two wooden railings. Continue past the lock to where the towpath intersects with the road, about 10 feet past the lock. Turn right onto the towpath and continue six tenths of a mile until the path forks. To the right is access to the aqueduct waterway. To the left is access to the aqueduct towpath. The waterway sits about six feet lower than the towpath. Select a path and walk another 350 feet to the aqueduct. On the waterway path you can see stone blocks forming walls on either side of you that are about 6 feet tall. On the towpath you can look down into the waterway on your right or look to the left at the river. The towpath has a fence on the river side and two-foot bumpers on the waterway side.

data.title: Rose River Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Fishers Gap Parking Area (mile 49.4) | A hike to a dazzling 67' waterfall. For most of this hike, you’ll be on a beautiful trail in one of the Park’s federally designated Wilderness areas.

images.altText: Color photo of a waterfall in the midst of the fresh spring green trees from a forest.
images.title: Rose River Falls

data.bodyText:
A hike to a dazzling 67 foot waterfall. For most of this hike, you’ll be on a beautiful trail in one of the Park’s federally designated Wilderness areas. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 4-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 4 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 910 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the Fishers Gap Parking Area (mile 49.4), cross Skyline Drive and start down the fire road.
  2. Just after the chain, take a left onto the Skyland-Big Meadows Horse Trail (yellow-blazed).
  3. In about 0.6-mile take the blue-blazed Rose River Loop Trail.
  4. Follow it past the 67-foot falls.
  5. Continue to the bridge, where you begin hiking up a steep, rocky section past beautiful cascades.
  6. At the fire road (yellow-blazed), turn right across bridge.
  7. For an added treat (and about .25-mile more hiking), you can take the Dark Hollow Falls Trail to the base of the falls and back.
  8. Then continue uphill about one mile back to Skyline Drive.

data.title: Snead Farm Loop Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Dickey Ridge Visitor Center (Mile 5.1) | Hike through old apple orchards and farmlands to an historic barn on the former Snead homesite.

images.altText: An old, white barn sits under a canopy of green trees
images.title: Snead Family Barn

data.bodyText:
Discover the cultural history of Shenandoah National Park as you hike to the historic Snead family barn. Pets must be on a physical leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. Note that, while allowed on Snead Farm Loop Trail, pets are not allowed on the adjacent Fox Hollow Trail.

Distance: 3.7-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hours 30 minutes
Elevation Gain: 580 feet

Hike Description 

  1. From the trailhead located across Skyline Drive from Dickey Ridge Visitor Center (mile 5.1), go right onto Dickey Ridge Trail.
  2. Go left on Snead Farm Road, which will take you to Snead Barn. For a shorter, 0.7-mile round-trip hike, turn around here and return to your starting point.
  3. To continue on the loop hike, stay on the Snead Farm Loop Trail to its intersection with the Dickey Ridge Trail.
  4. Turn right and follow it back to your starting point.
data.audioDescription: The Fox Hollow Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph of a single purple periwinkle blossom amid glossy green leaves. The text reads, "Home: Before this part of Virginia was called Shenandoah National Park, people lived here and called it home. This land is where they got their sustenance, made their living, raised their families, and buried their dead. You can still see evidence of former human habitation throughout the Park, including here in Fox Hollow. The daffodils and periwinkle you see are gone-wild descendants of plants nurtured by them; the cemetery, too, reminds us that they were here." The picture on the bottom left of the panel shows 3 tombstones from the Fox family cemetery. The stone in the center of the picture reads, "Gertrude Fox, Died June 22, 1904, Aged 21 Years". That stone has been broken near its base and is lying on an angle among the green ground cover. The text reads, "They Still Speak - There are more than 100 family cemeteries in Shenandoah. Some are still maintained by the descendants of those buried there and some are not. The cemeteries that are not as well maintained might surprise hikers who come across the weathered tombstones in the Park's backcountry. Whether or not they are kept up and taken care of, these cemeteries speak gently to us of the people who made their lives in the hollows and on the ridges of what is now Shenandoah National Park." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hikes to Fox Hollow Trail and Snead Farm Loop. The Fox Hollow Trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1: Fox Hollow Trail, 1.2 mile circuit, easiest, .75 hours hiking time, 310-foot elevation gain. Turn left onto Dickey Ridge Trail, then right onto Fox Hollow Trail. Stay on Fox Hollow Trail - past rock piles and the Fox family cemetery - back to the starting point." "Hike #2: Snead Farm Loop, (This hike is marked in purple with a dashed line.) 3.7 mile circuit, moderate, 2.5 hours hiking time, 580-foot elevation gain. Go right onto the Dickey Ridge Trail. Go left on the Snead Farm Road, which will take you to Snead Barn. Continue on the Snead Farm Loop Trail to its intersection with the Dickey Ridge Trail. Turn right and follow it back to your starting point." A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets are not allowed on Fox Hollow Trail. Where allowed, pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. Leave what you find. Artifacts are protected by law. Please respect family cemeteries."

data.title: South River Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription: South River Picnic Grounds Comfort Station (mile 62.7) | From the South River Picnic Grounds, this route is a circuit hike that takes you to an observation point overlooking an 83’ waterfall. A great hike for wildflower and bird enthusiasts, alike!

images.altText: A color photo showing a forest of green trees with a dirt trail underneath of them.
images.title: South River Falls Trail

data.bodyText:
From the South River Picnic Grounds, this route is a circuit hike that takes you to the base of a 83’ waterfall. A great hike for wildflower and bird enthusiasts, alike! This hike has one stream crossing. Pets must be on a physcial leash no longer than 6 feet at all times.

Distance: 3.3-mile circuit hike
Difficulty: Moderate (explanation of our hiking difficulty scale)
Hiking Time: 2 hour 15 minutes
Elevation Gain: 910 feet

Hike Description

  1. From the trailhead just below the South River Picnic Grounds Comfort Station (mile 62.7), take the blue-blazed South River Falls Trail.
  2. You'll cross the Appalachian Trail, but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled observation point.
  3. From the observation point, continue on the South River Falls Trail to the trailpost.
  4. Go left onto the yellow-blazed South River Falls Road. 
  5. The trail joins the South River Fire Road.
  6. Continue on the fire road to its intersection with the Appalachian Trail.
  7. Turn left and follow the A.T. (white-blazed) to its intersection with the South River Falls Trail.
  8. Go right to return to your starting point.
data.audioDescription: The South River Falls Trailhead panel is a 36 by 54 inch color poster. On the upper left of the panel is a photograph taken from the forest floor up toward the high, green, canopy with the light of the sky peeking through occasionally. The text reads, "Safe Harbor: It's different in this hollow. As you descend from the ridge top to South River Falls, you'll notice how things change. Little by little you'll find yourself surrounded by tall, wide trees - tulip trees, sugar maples, and white ashes. If it's spring, you'll smell oink azalea. You might hear the clear whistle and metallic chip of the Louisiana waterthrush, and the "tsee-tsee-tsee-tsway" of the American redstart. You're hiking through a specific type of ecosystem: Appalachian Rich Cove Forest. Wet conditions and rich soils provide perfect habitat for the animals and plants that live here. The east-facing slopes get plenty of rain and protection from harsh winds. You can find this environment elsewhere in Shenandoah National Park, but you won't see it outside the Appalachian Mountains." The picture on the bottom left of the panel is a handsome Louisiana waterthrush showing the brown stripes on its white breast. The text reads, "What Thrives Here: Migratory birds favor the wet forest and closed canopy of South River Falls. They travel from as far as Central and South America to live here in the summer. The Louisiana waterthrush, pictured here, is the only bird in the Park that always chooses a streamside habitat like that at South River Falls. The American redstart - a type of warbler - and scarlet tanager also live in these woods. Black cohosh, wild geraniums, and maidenhair fern enjoy the cool, wet forest around South River Falls." The top right of the panel is a 20 by 20 inch topographic map of the hike to South River Falls. The text reads, "Suggested Hikes: Hike #1 - South River Falls Observation Point (This trail is marked in yellow with a brown dashed line.) 2.6-mile round trip, moderate, 1.75 hours hiking time, 850-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Take blue-blazed South River Falls Trail. Cross the Appalachian Trail, but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled observation point. Retrace your steps to return." "Hike #2: South River Falls Loop (This trail is marked in purple with a brown dashed line.) 3.3 mile circuit , moderate, 2.25 hours hiking time, 910-foot elevation gain, one stream crossing. Take blue-blazed South River Falls Trail. Cross the Appalachian Trail (A.T.), but stay on the South River Falls Trail to the stone-walled falls observation point. Continue on South River Falls Trail to the trail post. Go left at the trail post; the trail is now blazed yellow. At the next trail post, go left. Ascend to the next intersection and trail post, where you will go left onto the white-blazed A.T. Continue south on the A.T. to the next intersection; go right on South River Falls Trail back to the starting point. A red text box below the map gives important information that hikers need. The text reads, "Emergency 1-800-732-0911 (cell phone service is unreliable.) Before You Go! Pets must be on a leash at all times. Be sure you are physically able to complete the hike you've chosen. Take plenty of water - at least a quart per hour Be sure you know your route. Free maps are available at entrance stations, visitors centers, and www.nps.gov/shen When you return from your hike, check for ticks. Stay on the trail and avoid trampling sensitive vegetation. Be sure someone knows where you are and when to expect your return. It's dangerous and potentially deadly to climb on the rocks near waterfalls. Filter or treat water from streams before drinking."
